A large bird wishes to mate with a little bird. The latter
says that she is going to swallow a large eel. The large bird sees the
absurdity of his proposal. Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 104.

Not more absurd than crow claiming swan as wife. India:
*Thompson-Balys.
If his head is taken off other punishments do not matter.

Judge shows criminal
mercy: he will not punish him as he deserves, only take off his head. Nouvelles
Récréations No. 82.
Turning king into Brahmin like turning donkey into horse.
Pot full of milk as sign that city is full of fakirs;

flower on top of milk not disturbing it as sign that one
more will not matter. India: Thompson-Balys.

Butcher buyer demands saddle and ornaments along with
camel (or the like). Seller later buys all heads in butcher shop: demands heads
of butcher’s family. India: *Thompson-Balys.

Question: How can black beans make a white soup? Answer: How can a white whip
on the naked flesh make black welts. *Wesselski Arlotto II 252 No. 168.

Why is it that black cow eats green grass, gives white milk
and yellow butter?

Answer: The same reason
blackberries are red when they are green. U.S.: Baughman.

Theological questions answered by propounding simple
questions in science.

Where was God before
he made heaven and earth? and the like answered by “Why a louse bite raises a
blister, a flee bite raises a swelling, and a gnat bite is unnoticeable?” If
you cannot answer such simple questions how can you pry into God’s secrets.
*Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 97.
How many priests should one have in one place?

How many fox tails will reach to heaven? All depends on
the length of the tails. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 96.
How much cloth would it take to make God‘s coat?

Just as much as for me, for what you have done for a poor
person in my name you have done for me. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 325.
“In this sesame flower where is the oil?”

“When your mother conceived where were you?” India:
Thompson-Balys.

content:
A husband planning to punish his wife, who has yawned in church at the same
time as a man, sees his error when his wife in the woods calls out, ”The
squirrels hop from bough to bough as the yawns from mouth to mouth.“ Finnish:
Aarne FFC VIII 6 No. 23; XXXIII 52 No. 23; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 141 No. 12;
Livonian: Loorits FFC LXVI 84 No. 35.

Repartee regarding the parentage of
children--miscellaneous.
child:
Mother of twelve on deathbed explains to family that not all her children are
legitimate. Gives the paternity of each child. Youngest leaves his food to say:
“Please, mother, give me a good father!” (Cf. †J325.) Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Even God can overdo it! Returning sailor finds his hovel
transformed into a fine house.

“Where does
all this come from?” Wife: “God’s bounty.” Illegitimate child greets mother.
Same question, same answer. Sailor: “I don‘t want God to help me so much!”
Italian Novella: *Rotunda

Suitor hesitates to marry girl as immature (or too
delicate).

Girl’s father protests, saying
that she has had three children. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

The children of the Genoese are strong because there is
more help. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content: Eunuch visits augurer to see whether he is to be a father.

“When I look at the livers, you are to be a father. When I
look at you, I see that you are not even a man.” Wienert FFC LVI 40; Babrius
No. 54.

Of three brothers the shoemaker makes shoes for the queen and princess; the
tailor, clothes; the fool--children. Type 1548*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No.
654A.
Children by day and by night.
His father has been in Rome.

A young man comes to
Rome who looks like the emperor. Latter asks him if he mother has ever been in
Rome. No, but my father has been here often. (Not son but brother.) *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 502; Mensa Philosophica No. 3; Nouvelles Récréations No. 15; Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

child: Child born one month after marriage.

Father-in-law to son-in-law: “Do like my grandson and you
will always be ahead of others.” Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Child born two months after marriage. Husband returns wife to her father
(uncle) saying: “I can’t afford a child every two months.” Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

Groom leaves. Can‘t afford a child every time he lies with
his wife. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 29; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

content: Wine gives ambassador courage to address Pope.

”Another drink and I could have slapped his face!“ Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

A
thief condemned to the gallows tells the king, “I do what you do and it is
against my will.” King: “You shall also be hanged against your will.” *Basset
1001 Contes I 507.
Do not leave it to your successor.

A widow stops a ruler on his way to war. He may be killed
and he should not leave the act of justice as a credit to his successor.
*Chauvin VIII 204 No. 246; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
child: Show me how it is done.

Wronged woman thus addresses ruler, who is indifferent to insults directed at
him. She wishes to be shown how to bear insults. This rebukes him. Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

A
widow asks justice of a king. The latter says that he is too busy to hear her.
“Then cease being a king,” replies the widow. Her bold reply wins an audience
with the king. Spanish: Childers.

content:
A
peasant goes to a judge and thinking to gain his favor addresses him with high
titles. The judge calls him a fool. “I was mistaken, you swine!” *Wesselski
Hodscha Nasreddin I 262 No. 223.
“If I were a tyrant you would not say so.”

Answer made by emperor to one who calls him a tyrant.
*Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 733; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

A king gives a man a coin. “Is that all you give your brother?” “Are you my
brother?” “Surely, we both pray, Our father, etc.” “If all your brothers give
you as much as I you will be rich.” Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 517.

To be rewarded by ruler with a coin, an ass, a sheep, or a
vineyard. Answers that he will take the coin, mount the ass, drive the sheep
into the vineyard, and there pray for the ruler. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin
II 237 No. 523.

child:
A
judge asks a pseudo-prophet to prove his powers by opening a difficult lock. “I
am a prophet, not a locksmith.” Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 258 No. 198.

Peasant tells bishop, who rides by with forty horses, that he
wonders if St. Kilian at Würzburg is also riding with forty horses. Bishop
excuses extravagance by saying that he is also a prince and that it is the
prince, not the bishop, who is using the horses. “If the prince should become a fool, what would the bishop do then?”
Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 158.
Will not try to correct them.

Pope calls persistent courtier a fool. Latter says that
there are people who call the pope the same thing and that he for one will not
try to correct them. Frey (ed. Bolte) 222 No. 17.

Philosopher asks ruler for money Ruler says that philosophers do not need
money. Philosopher: “If I am rewarded, I will say that you are right; I will no
longer need money.” Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Shivering king (rich man) to tattered peasant: “Aren’t you cold?” Peasant: “No,
if you wore all your clothes as I do, you wouldn‘t be cold either!” Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

King to son who has been accused of rape: “I never did anything like that.”
Prince: “Your father was not king!” King: “Your son will never be one if you
keep that up!” Spanish: Childers; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Shoemaker speaks ill of lord‘s rule.

Lord takes his tools away from him. Shoemaker begs for
them saying that he cannot carry on his business without them. Ruler: “I
thought ruling was your business so I took your tools to learn shoemaking.”
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
One ear saved for other litigant.

Judge stops up one ear while first litigant presents his
case. He is saving one ear for the second litigant. Spanish: Childers.
Seek harmony in your own house.

King brought to sense of duty by philosopher who tells him
to seek harmony in his own house before inquiring about the harmony in his
kingdom. Spanish: Childers.

A philosopher of the city came to him asking mercy for it
King said he would do nothing he asked. Philosopher then asked him to destroy
the city. This saves the city. Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Man, fined for sabbath-breaking, asks for receipt,

explains that if God asks for it, he will not have to
journey to hell to get it from the judge. U.S.: Baughman.

he is so drunk that trial must be postponed. When he is
tried later, he is told how at the earlier trial he had kept repeating that the
judge was a very wise judge. When he hears this he admits that he must have
been very drunk. U.S.: Baughman.

Weaver hearing of tax for every doorway of weavers takes
his door to the khan: will not return for the sidewalls of his house.

Gem offered by monarch to one who can first go around the
kingdom.

Trickster goes around king and
says king is kingdom. India: Thompson-Balys.
Thief serves king buffaloes he has killed in hunt and lost;

thus reproaches king’s wastefulness. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Hairless palms from giving and receiving gold.
Jester flatters prince for bounty. India: Thompson-Balys.

Emperor: “What people have the biggest bellies?” Jester
answers: “The landlords.”

Holy man asked by king for the heart of religion answers:
“You are sitting on your throne and I‘m sitting on the ground, so how can I
tell.”

Tailor caught resting his head on royal robe while he rests
tells king there is no better resting place for king’s robe, for “the head is
the king of the body.”

King to smoker: “Even donkeys will have nothing to do with
tobacco.”

Smoker: “Donkeys don‘t know how
to enjoy themselves.” India: Thompson-Balys.

content: The fairest thing in the garden.

Three brothers asked by princess what is the most
beautiful thing in the garden. The youngest replies, “Yourself.” He wins the
princess. Type 925*.

He
dreams that he receives nine coins. He demands ten. He wakes and finds that he
has dreamed. He is willing to accept the nine. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I
206 (No. 5); Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child:
A
man prays for a thousand gold pieces and says that he will not accept one less.
A joker sends him 999. He says that he will trust God for the other coin.
*Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 220ff. No. 54.

content: To be rewarded by his kind.

Unworthy person is rewarded. Asks worthy one: ”Why is it
that I am rewarded and you are not?“ Answer: ”Because you have found more of
your kind that I have of mine.“ (Also told of Dante and a minstrel.) Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

Reproached with his mutilation, the eunuch says that his ill fortune is no
shame. The only shame is to merit what you suffer. Wienert FFC LVI 82 (ET 485),
149 (ST 546).

A hide is in the river. River: “What is your name?” Hide: “Hard hide.” River:
“Hunt another name; I’ll soon soften you.” Wienert FFC LVI 75 (ET 403), 101 (ST
148); Halm Aesop No. 381.
Too late for the same advice.

Impoverished spendthrift sarcastically to thrifty person:
”Stop spending so freely!“ ”It‘s too late to give you the same advice.“ Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

A
sailor says that all his ancestors have drowned. Citizen: “Aren’t you afraid of
drowning?” Sailor: “How did your ancestors die?” Citizen: “All of them in bed.”
Sailor: “Aren‘t you afraid to go to bed?” *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 264.

A
peddler scolds the dog who is waiting and tells him to get ready to go with
him. The dog replies that he has nothing to carry, that it is the peddler who
is late. Wienert FFC LVI 73 (ET 379), 125 (ST 343).
Husband and wife burn their mouths.

A wife served overhot soup, forgets and burns herself so
that tears come to her eyes She says that her departed father liked soup so
much that she weeps when she eats it. The husband is also burned and weeps: “I
am weeping because your accursed mother didn‘t take you with her when she
died.”
Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 238 No. 115; Köhler-Bolte I 498; Indonesian:
Coster-Wijsman 71 No. 129.
child:
Says that he is crying because so many have left the
monastery. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content: Monk says that he is a stallion.

In reply to women’s taunts he boasts of his powers. A
woman calls on the devil to come and ride him. Bolte Frey 253 No. 97.

child: Man decides to spend 100 florins to become known.

Friend: ”You had better spend 200 so as to not be found
out.“ Italian Novella: Rotunda.

An old man says of a youthful prodigy: ”He will be an idiot in old age because
perfection before maturity brings on deterioration of the mind.“ Youth: ”You
must have been very wise in your youth!“ Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Two men meet in narrow passage.

One says: ”I do not give every coxcomb the wall!“ The
other says: ”I do, sir!“ England: Baughman.

Person asks: ”Whose fool are you?“ Answer: ”I am the Bishop
of Durham‘s fool; whose fool are you?“ England: *Baughman.

Why soldier is silent before king: is always so when
questioned by stupid person.

content: Fool frightened by stirring of the wind.

Falls on a knife and kills himself. Africa (Ibo, Nigeria):
Basden 277.
Tailor puts on thimble as protection from slug.
Fright at the creaking of a wheelbarrow.
child: North Carolina: Brown Collection I 697; India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Fools frightened by stirring of an animal.
child: Fools are frightened at the humming of bees.

Think it is a drum. *BP II 555; Christensen DF XLVII
194ff. No. 20.
Fools frightened at the flight of a quail.

When they hear ”whirr!“ the army flees. Africa (Thonga):
Junod 247.

Lions flee because of the crowing of white cock, elephants
because of swine‘s grunting.

content:
Coward boasts of what he would have done after danger is
over.
child:
Admits guilt. Husband: ”Had you denied it I would have
killed you!“ Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content: Person frightened into falling down a cliff.

N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 303 n. 109f.; West Indies:
Flowers 492.
Coward is frightened when clothing catches on thistle.

Fool worries lest earthquake make him fall against an open knife. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Fool steps on a rake and falls down crying, ”I surrender!“ *BP II 555.
The hawk frightened at the snipe’s bill.

The snipe: ”It is a bill, but it is good for nothing
(weak).“ The hawk is no longer afraid. Type 229*; Russian: Andrejev No. 229.

A
man awakes with his knees in the air. He thinks the knees are a lion and splits
them with his axe. Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 407 No. 5.

Fools try to frighten one another, but get scared
themselves and both flee.

Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 3444; Legends Nos. 867, 869f.
The dead girl frightens father and lover.

The girl dies. The lover, thinking that she is asleep,
talks to her. When he hears the father speak of her as dead he is frightened
that he has talked to the dead. The father hears the lover talk and thinks that
it is the girl’s spirit. Both flee. Africa (Vai): Ellis 204 No. 21.
Fright at animals‘ eyes in the dark.
Tiger frightened of leak in house.
Boastful coward frightened when he sees strong adversaries.

Hides in trousers of plowman who fights the men.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *650B; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 650B; Finnish:
Aarne FFC V, XXXIII No. 650B; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 261f. No. 129.
The sleeper answers for the dead man.

A man falls asleep by a gallows. A company of wags come
and invite the dead man on the gallows to accompany them. The sleeper awakes
with a start and says, ”I‘ll come at once.“ The wags flee in terror. *Wesselski
Bebel II 119 No. 59; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Seven men make strenuous
plans for the attack on the fierce animal. One screams with fright and the
animal runs away. (Cf. †J1736.1.) *BP II 556, III 286; Christensen DF XLVII 220
No. 82; Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 307 No. 34.

Choice of eating 100 onions, receiving 100 blows, or paying 100 coins. Fool
tries onions in vain, then the blows, and finally must give the coins.
*Zachariae Kleine Schriften 170; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 349; India:
Thompson-Balys.
Expensive wood burned to make charcoal.

Stupid boy convinced that trading all his silver for
worthless cup will gain people‘s respect.
Thief warned what not to steal.

The numskull tells the thief where his door-key, his
cakes, and his roasts are and warns him not to steal them. *Bolte Zs. f. Vksk.
IX 87.
child: Fool hides treasure and leaves sign “Here it is.”

Thief leaves sign “Here it is not.” Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
74; Mensa Philosophica No. 141.

content: Valuables given away or sold for trifle.
child:
Numskull gives away the old water bag in which the money is
hid.
Woman gives a jewel for a salad.

The recipient is also a numskull and doesn’t know its
value. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 30.
Fool ignorant of value of jewel throws it away.

Boy refuses pearls for worthless stones; jeweler recognizes
them for what they are.

Good timber given for useless because wife says they will
have only sickness and trouble.
Sacks of gold and silver traded for sacks of rice.
Gold and jewels sold for trifle.

content:
A man finds a treasure, but is robbed by
porters whom he has employed to rid him of the trouble of carrying it. Chauvin
II 82 No. 2; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 179; B[ö]dker Exempler 272 No. 2; Spanish
Exempla: Keller.

To see whether the church is moving someone
lays down his coat in front of it. It is stolen. They think that the church has
passed over it. Type 1326; Köhler-Bolte I 324; Christensen DF L 218 No. 79.
Wife persuades her husband to have a good tooth pulled.

Type 1406; Bédier
Fabliaux 266ff.; Herbert III 20; *Crane Vitry 238 No. 248; Boccaccio Decameron
VII No. 9 (Lee 231); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Numskull believes that he is married to a man.

Two men’s hands joined in fun with words ”I marry you.“
Fool thinks that he must get a bishop to annul the marriage. Wesselski Bebel II
142 No. 130.

Drunken man made to believe that he has been to heaven and
hell.

He
is dressed up as a rich lord and given rich food and drink. When put back into
his own clothes he thinks that he has been to heaven. *Type 1531; Köhler-Bolte
I 68; Wesselski Archiv Orientální I (1929) 80 f.; Shakespeare Induction to
Taming of the Shrew; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

An
apprentice, or newcomer or ignorant person, etc., is sent for absurd or
misleading or nonexistent object or on a ridiculous quest. Canada, England,
U.S.: *Baughman.
Near-sighted man persuaded by doctor that he can see.

A student tells a woman that he comes from Paris. She
understands him to say from paradise and gives him money and goods to take to
her husband. *Type 1540; **Aarne FFC XXII 3--109; *Clouston Noodles 204--217
passim; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 463; *Wesselski Bebel I 189 No. 50; Christensen
DF L 35; Indonesia: Coster-Wijsman 73 No. IV.
child:
Foolish woman gives swindler money for her parents in
heaven.
Dream explained as a dead father’s demand for horses.
Dupe gives them to trickster. India: Thompson-Balys.
Emperor wants to travel to paradise.
Blindfolded and put on an ass. India: Thompson-Balys.

Alleged messenger from relatives in distress given goods to
deliver.

content:
Husband made to believe that yarn has changed to tow
through his carelessness.

Thus his lazy
wife is relieved from spinning. Type 1405; BP III 44.
child:
Fool believes gold in bag turns to ashes because of child‘s
urinating on it.

Actually bag contained
only ashes. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Husband refuses to believe in wife‘s infidelity.
child:
Husband refuses to believe that his wife is unfaithful,
even when she is caught in the act.

Husband away three years accepts children born in his
absence as his own.

Woman gives birth to child fourteen months after husband’s
departure.

The latter is made to believe
it is legitimate. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Woman tells husband that she has become pregnant during
his absence according to his own instructions. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
She knows best: woman denies accusation of adultery.

Husband dismisses the truthful accusers saying that she
knows her shortcomings better than anyone else, and she denies it. Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

Rascal tests it and finds it lacking. India:
*Thompson-Balys.
Only husband remains ignorant about his wife’s infidelity.

content:
(Cf. †J2311.0.1., †J2311.2, †J2311.7, †J2312, †J2313, †J2314,
†J2315, †J2316, †J2324, †J2331.) *Types 1313, 1406; *Liebrecht Zur Volkskunde
124; Bédier Fabliaux 265ff., 475; *Crane Vitry 227 No. 231; *Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin I 225 No. 66; *BP III 337; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 866; B[ö]dker
Exempler 280, 296 Nos. 24, 59; Christensen DF XLVII 59; Spanish Exempla:
Keller; India: Thompson-Balys.
child:
Husband takes back faithless wife on her oath to be
faithful.
His wife has become a widow.

Numskull buys cloth used only by widows and is therefore
convinced. India: Thompson-Balys.

Gullible husband removes from wife’s garment dust gathered
while she lies with another man.
Dupe is made to believe horse will fly.
Wife makes husband believe that her paramour is Death.

Credulous king reads about ocean of milk and its
properties.
The woman who asked for news from home.

Gets many impossible answers, which she believes. E.g.,
”The cock has become sexton.“--”Yes, that is why he sang so well in the
morning.“
(First edition †X941.) *Type 1931.

content: Dupe is persuaded that money will grow if he buries it.
Dreams he is being kissed by fairy. Is really a pig. India: Thompson-Balys.
Man made to believe that he is pregnant (has borne child).
child: Parson made to believe that he will bear a calf.

In having his urine examined by a doctor, a cow‘s is substituted by
mistake. (Or he dreams that he has borne a calf.) When a calf comes into the
house he thinks that he has borne it. (Cf. †J1734.1, †K1955.2.) *Type 1739; *BP
I 317 n. 1; *Fb ”kalv“; *Wesselski Bebel I 232
No. 148.
Man thinks he has given birth to a child by letting wind.

Italian: Basile Pentamerone II No. 3; Christensen DF XLVII
228 No. 93.

Husband makes wife and mother-in-law believe he will bear a
sheep.

His wife was pregnant when he
married her. Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.

content: Man who asks for good weather given a box full of hornets.

He thinks that it is
filled with the weather. Köhler-Bolte I 324.
Numskull with unimportant office boasts of it.
child: Proud sheriff has only nine farmers in his jurisdiction.
Fool appointed to fictitious office boasts of it.

”Administrador de la yesca.“ Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 138 No.
1689A*; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

content:
Fool locked in dark room made to believe that it is
continuous night.

Spanish: Boggs FFC XC
137 No. 1684; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
The sledges turned in the direction of the journey.
At night turned around by a joker. Type 1275.

Master persuaded to buy big fish since small ones creep out
of all parts of his body.

Hunters shoot a stag and hide it. Another who sees puts a dead ass in
the bag instead. When the bag is opened, one cries, ”Oh Jesus, we have shot a
stag with iron shoes!“ Köhler-Bolte I 325.

Jewess makes parents believe that she is to give birth to
the Messiah.

She bears a girl. *Wesselski Mönchslatein 65 No. 53; *Wesselski
Bebel I 213 No. 104; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *1864; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Dupe persuaded that he is invisible.

Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 3 (Lee 254); Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Husband made to believe that his house has moved during his
absence.

The wife and her confederates transform the house into an inn with tables,
signs, drinkers, etc. The husband cannot find his house. *Type 1406; *Wesselski
Hodscha Nasreddin I 274 No. 298; Bédier Fabliaux 266; Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.
child:
Man cannot recognize his own house which has been turned
into a mansion by emperor.

content: Well man made to believe that he is sick.

*Chauvin VI 138 No. 291; Clouston Noodles 161; Clouston
Tales II 30ff.; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 869.
child: Man thinks that he has diabetes.

Rascals have sewed his trouser leg till it is too tight.
Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 680.

content: Layman made to believe that he is a monk.

*Type 1406; *Bédier
Fabliaux 265, 468; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 866; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.
Wife persuades husband that she has returned immediately.

She goes to a neighbor’s to cook a fish. She is gone a week. She
gets a new fish and cooks it and returns home with the hot fish. She convinces
her husband of her short absence. Type 1406; Bédier Fabliaux 265, 458.
child: Wife leaves home, offers self to lover.

Returning persuades husband that she has not been away.
Irish myth: Cross; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Gullible husband made to believe he has cut off his wife‘s
nose.

She, in another house, has had her
nose cut off by mistake. She makes him believe he has done it by making him
angry enough to throw a razor at her. When he throws the razor she claims it
has cut off her nose. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Naked person made to believe that he is clothed.

*Types 1406, 1620; *Clouston Noodles 163; *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 866; H. C. Andersen ”Kejserens ny Klæder“; Christensen
DF L 64; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Person made to believe that he is dead.
child: Wife makes her husband believe that he is dead.

Numskull is told that he is to die when his horse breaks
wind three times.

When this happens he
lies down for dead. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 216f. No. 49; *Fb ”æsel“; Köhler-Bolte I 135, 486, 505.
Man believes he is to die when he breaks wind.
Lies down for dead. India: Thompson-Balys.
Numskull is told that he will die when his mouth bleeds.
Man believes, he will die when water falls on his head.

Numskull believes he is dead when pumpkin falls on his
head.

Man believes he will die when he gets a scarlet thread on
his coat.

Fool, told yellowing soles of his feet sure sign he is
going to die, digs his grave and lies in it.

The wife tells the husband that a certain pot of preserves is poison. He
decides to kill himself and eats the preserves. He believes that he is poisoned
and lies down for dead. *Type 1313; *BP III 337; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin
II 237 No. 522; *Wesselski Morlini 49; *Bolte Frey 214; *Clouston Noodles 122;
Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 4.

A man
takes refuge from robbers in an open grave. Robbers see him and ask what he is
doing. ”It is my grave. I went out to get a breath of air.“ Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin I 206 No. 6.

A numskull who has lain down thinking he is dead is carried off in a bier. The
carriers lose their way. He speaks up, ”I always went that way when I was
alive.“ Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 216f. No. 49; Italian Novella: *Rotunda;
India: Thompson-Balys. Cf. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 860.
The dead man in spite of himself.

Neighbors who have heard of the numskull’s death insist on
the funeral although he is alive and well. He is persuaded and is carried on a
bier. They meet a busy man whom they try to persuade to join them. He pleads
business. The ”dead“ man speaks: ”It‘s no use, friend, to try to dissuade
them.“ *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 239 No. 121; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Supposed dead man on bier threatens his bearers.

A numskull lies in an old grave to see the Day of Judgment. He hears bells and
thinks that the Last Day has come. He is beaten by mule-drivers when he tells
them that he is a dead man. He returns home and tells his wife that he returns
from the dead. ”How goes it in heaven?“ ”For one thing, avoid mule-drivers.“
*Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 216 No. 46.
Cold hands and feet for the dead man.

His wife has told him that one tells a dead person by his
cold hands and feet. He freezes his feet and hands and lies down for dead.
Wolves eat his ass. ”Lucky for you that his master is dead!“ *Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin I 225 No. 66; India: *Thompson-Balys.

Parents made to believe that they are dead and are married
to each other again.

Indonesia: DeVries’s
list No. 270, Coster-Wijsman 73 No. 11.

Foolish peasants carry couple to burial; when ”corpses“
speak they flee in terror.
Drunken man insists that he be beheaded.

Is struck with the flat of his sword. He thinks he is
dead. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 6; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Idiot tells his mother he has been dead twelve years.
Supposed dead man roused with whip.

content:
Adulteress makes husband believe that the birth of her
mulatto child has been due to suggestion.
Numskull convinced that he is a thief.

An article is stolen. Declared that whoever does not eat
all his cheese is the thief. A stone is put in the numskull’s cheese so that he
cannot eat it all. He admits the theft. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 679.

Opium-smoker on journey asks his way about; ends up at his
own house.

child: Woman exchanges a horse for a sack of bones.

She has been falsely told that the sack is filled with
gold. Type 2007*.

content:
His pupils grab a dog‘s tail and think it is their
master’s.
Fool does not recognize his own house and family.

Man does not recognize his name when it is called: he is
accustomed to hear his nickname.

A
numskull ties yarn around the stove to keep the heat from escaping. Type
1271B*.

Numskull tries to find the time of night. Clouston Noodles
76; England: Baughman.
child: Sundial covered in order to protect it.

content: How far his voice will reach.

A numskull cries from a tower and then runs away to see
how far his voice will reach. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 191 No. 373.
As tired as if he had walked.

So says the numskull after riding to town on his stick
horse. *Wesselski Bebel II 158 No. 182.
Trying to get fruit from fruitless tree.
child: Numskulls try to get pears from an oaktree.

They accuse each other of eating all the pears. Wesselski
Bebel II 147 No. 149.

content:
Numskull stretches out his hands toward the fire across
the river. Clouston Noodles 68.
Demand that murderer restore life to victim.
child:
Woman runs after guest to tell him he must restore her
husband whom he has unintentionally killed.

content: Fire and water mixed to make sacrifice.
Fool told that he needed only the two. Penzer V 68.

child:
Simpleton drives goats into a well, because he thinks it
would be cooler for them.
Hot sickle put into water to cure its fever.

Fool loses his mother’s corpse on way to funeral. Mistakes
old woman for mother and substitutes her. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Absurd attempt to change animal nature.
child:
A man has a cat trained to hold up lighted
candles on its head. The king has a mouse let loose. The cat drops the candle
and chases the mouse. *Type 217; **Cosquin Études 403ff.; *Fb “kat” IV 255a; *Wesselski Arlotto II 238 No. 131; India:
*Thompson-Balys.
Cat transformed to maiden runs after mouse.

*Hertel Zs. f. Vksk. XXII 244; **Rohde Kleinere Schriften
II 212ff.; Wienert FFC LVI *45, 71, 78 (ET 34, 351, 444), 86 (ST 1); Halm Aesop
No. 88; Jacobs Aesop 218 No. 76; Spanish: Espinosa III 275-277; Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Africa (Nama): Des
Schwartzen Menschen Märchenweisheit (Stuttgart, 1929) 140f. No. 27.

content:
Absurd disregard of animal‘s nature or
habits--miscellaneous.
child: Fisherman fails to make fish dance to his flute.

Later in his net they jump about without the aid of the
flute. Wienert FFC LVI *66 (ET 301), 117 (ST 275); Halm Aesop 27.

Fool tries to shoot dead antelope until it will come to
him.
Numskull tries to shake birds from tree like fruit.
Breeding fine horses from an ass.

Fool says, “Just as soon as the body of a colt bred from
this mare is in proper proportion to its ears you will have a fine horse.”
Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 763.
Sheep licking her lamb is envied by the wolf.

He says, “Such is bad conduct. If I were to do that they
would say that I was eating it.” Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 587; Spanish: Boggs FFC
XC 33 No. 129*. Cf. Wienert FFC LVI *69 (ET 335), 94f. (ST 81); Halm Aesop Nos.
282, 330.
Numskull tries to wash black hen white.
Fear that frog may drown or get dirty.

content:
The needle (or the like) falls into the sea: sought the
next summer.

child: Marking the place on the boat.

An object falls into the sea from a boat. Numskulls mark
the place on the boat-rail to indicate where it fell. *Type 1278; *Fb “båd” IV 87a; *Clouston Noodles 99; Penzer V 92f.; Japanese:
Ikeda.
Marking the place under the cloud.

Numskulls leave a knife in the field, marking the place by
putting it under a heavy cloud. Next day the cloud is gone and the knife lost.
Clouston Noodles 53; England: Baughman; Japanese: Ikeda.

Fool seeks the ears of grain in the direction of the cloud
toward which he has sowed them.
Marking the place in the sand.

Vessel left under mound in sand while owner is swimming.
Others make similar mounds so that it is lost. India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
Numskull looks for bread that he threw away a year before.
Africa (Zulu): Callaway 359.

Numskull forgets name of certain food and thinks that it
has fallen into sand.

child: Numskull throws money to frogs so that they can count it.
Numskull feeds his wheat to frogs.

He has been sent to mill to have it ground. Spanish: Boggs
FFC XC 139 No. *1693, Espinosa III 147.
Numskull throws money to frogs to repay them.

They have frightened his fleeing ass from the water.
*Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 226 No. 69.
Wool taken to pond for frogs and toads to weave.

Numskulls hear birds calling and give them gifts. Indonesia: DeVries’s list No.
260.

Thankful numskull puts money in the anus of sheep which he
supposes has helped him.

content: *Type 1642; *BP I 59f.; *Chauvin VI 126 No. 280; Fansler MAFLS XII 352.
child:
When he comes for his
money the bird flies to a trash pile, where the fool finds a treasure. (Cf.
†J1853.1.1.) *Clouston Noodles 147.
Fool sells balls of thread to great lizard.
Next day he finds a treasure there. India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
*Type 1642; *BP I 59; Köhler-Bolte I 135;
Spanish: Espinosa III 147.
child: Fool sells goods to a statue.

He is told not to sell to talkative people. The statue is
the only one he can find who is not talkative. *Chauvin VI 126 No. 280;
*Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 211 No. 426; Fansler MAFLS XII 352; Clouston
Noodles 144; Spanish: Espinosa III 147; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 4.

Fool sells goods to a
statue and when it will not pay him knocks it to pieces. He finds a treasure
inside. (Cf. †J1852.1.) Type 1643; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 211 No. 426;
Wienert FFC LVI 80 (ET 459), 138 (ST 430); Halm Aesop No. 66; Chauvin VIII 94
No. 65; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 4.

content: Absurd ignorance concerning the laying of eggs.
child:
A
woman wants her hen to lay many eggs. Overfeeds her and she stops laying
altogether. Wienert FFC LVI 72 (ET 362), 106 (ST 184); Halm Aesop No. 111.
Numskull feeds hens hot water so they will lay boiled eggs.

content: Numskull tries to dig up a well (spring).

He wants to take it
home. Köhler-Bolte I 533; Clouston Noodles 67.

child:
*DeVries FFC LXXIII 246; *Fb “så” Penzer V 67 n. 3; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese:
Ikeda.
Sowing cheese to bring forth a cow.

*Type 1200; Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 209 No. 423;
Christensen DF XLVII 206, 231 no. 57; India: Thompson-Balys.
Planting a hog in order to grow pigs.
Planting animal‘s tail in order to produce young animals.
Harvesting early for half a crop.
Stones watered to make them grow.

content:
Money tested by throwing it into a stream to see if it will
swim.

Good coins are supposed to swim,
counterfeit to sink. *Type 1651; BP II 75; *Fb “penge” II 804a; Russian:
Andrejev No. 842*.

child: Dead man identified by his cough.

Numskull asked to identify corpse tries to do so by his
cough. Clouston Noodles 15.
A healthy place for a tomb.

Numskull objects to unhealthy place for his tomb. Clouston
Noodles 9.

content: How he looks in his sleep.

A man stands before mirror with his eyes shut to see how
he looks in his sleep. Clouston Noodles 9.
child:
Man takes mirror to bed to see whether he sleeps with his
mouth open.

A peasant hangs boots and an accompanying letter on a telegraph wire, expecting
them to reach the city. Type 1710; Christensen DF XLVII 204 no. 50; U.S.
(Ozarks): *Randolph Devil‘s Pretty Daughter (New York, 1955) 195.

content: A hole to throw the earth in.

Numskull plans to dig a hole so as to have a place to
throw the earth from his excavation. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 227 No.
480; Christensen DF XL VII 201 no. 37; Jewish: Neuman.

They put meal in the boiling current of the ice hole and then, one
after another, they jump in to taste the porridge. Type 1260; Clouston Noodles
44; Field Pent Cuckoo 17; Christensen DF XLVII 178; India: Thompson-Balys;
Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 255.

child:
Rider takes the meal-sack on his shoulder to relieve the
ass of his burden.

*Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin II 229 No. 490; *Fb “sæk” III 720b; *Clouston Noodles
19; Field Pent Cuckoo 3; England, U.S.: Baughman; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Man puts bag of meal on one side of saddle, balances it on
the other side with a rock.

A fool eats nuts. A kernel slips from him. The fool:
“Everything tries to escape from death.” *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 183
No. 346.

The woman thinks the boiling pot is complaining. Type
1264*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1264.

Numskulls try to take home a wave of the sea in a bamboo rod. At home when it refuses
to wave they say that it is homesick for its mother, the sea. Indonesia:
DeVries’s list No. 252.

Numskull
thinks money piece covered with perspiration after he has held it for awhile is
weeping. India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
Numskull hears limbs creaking in the wind. He is sorry for them and holds them
apart. While he is caught between them his enemies take advantage of him. N. A.
Indian: *Thompson Tales 297 n. 85.
child:
When the wagon stops its creaking, fool decides it has died; he cremates it.
India: Thompson-Balys.

A
numskull climbs a tree to help a cuckoo so that he may call louder than the one
in the neighboring forest. Meanwhile his horse is eaten by a wolf. *Wesselski
Bebel I 137 No. 42.

Fool makes shoes for animals as well as men, since he
expects a cold winter.
Cloak given to a stone to keep it warm.

Köhler-Bolte I 71;
Christiansen Norske Eventyr 140 No. 1651; Japanese: Ikeda.

King orders houses built to keep howling jackals warm in
winter.

content:
Numskull sees cracks in
the ground and feels so sorry for them that he greases them with the butter he
is taking home. *Type 1291; BP I 521; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 250 No.
165; Missouri French: Carrière.

child:
Bullock struck on hindquarters instead of head in attempt
to kill it.

content: Absurd ignorance concerning place for animal to be kept.
child: Cow (hog) taken to roof to graze.

Fools
build an enclosure to keep in the cuckoo. She flies over the hedge. They say
that they have not built the hedge high enough. **Field Pent Cuckoo; Clouston
Noodles 27; England: Baughman.

Fools try to hedge the cuckoo so that they will have summer
the year round (the coming of the first cuckoo being the sign of the coming
summer).
Deer belled and enclosed like goats jump fence and escape.
Hogs made to sleep in trees to cure their filthy habits.
Nest built in tree for fish.
Fish will climb trees like buffaloes.

Numskull considers what will happen if river burns up.
India: *Thompson-Balys.

Fool does not milk cow for a month so that she will give
plenty for a feast.
Fools try to milk male ass.

The brother who owns the front end tries to drive the cow and will not
let the owner of the rear end milk her. India: Thompson-Balys.

Fool asks owner of oxen why he does not milk them since he
is not working them.
Trying to have cows make curds before being milked.
Cow killed in order to get all the milk at once.

content: Absurd ignorance concerning the hatching of eggs.
child: Numskull sits on eggs to finish the hatching.

Cautions people to be
quiet and not frighten the eggs. (Sometimes puts on honey and feathers before
sitting on the eggs.) Type 650; *BP I 316; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 212
No. 433; *Wesselski Bebel II 146 No. 148; Christensen DF XLVII 210 No. 63; Breton:
Sébillot Incidents s.v. “oeuf”; Spanish:
Espinosa III 147 Nos. 181--188; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 4.
Numskull tries to hatch out a calf from a cheese.

content: Absurd ignorance concerning animal‘s eating and drinking.
child: The water on the calf’s back.

When the calf will not drink, the peasant woman throws the
water on its back. Type 1211*.

When the customer refuses to take the milk he puts it back
into the goat‘s mouth so that it will flow back into the udder. *Wesselski
Hodscha Nasreddin II 247 No. 550.

A
farmer who wanted to fatten a pig fed it only twice a day. When told to feed it
three times a day he says, “A working man must have more to eat than a pig.”
*Wesselski Bebel I 141 No. 56.
How can an elephant eat, having tails at both ends?
Decision: it lives on air. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Absurd sympathy for animals or objects--miscellaneous.
child: Men drag carts on to roof to shade it from the sun.

A trickster cuts off the bill and legs of a stork to make him look more like a
real bird. Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 213 No. 37.

A fool is asked where the river is fordable. He says, “Everywhere.” The man
tries to ride across and is almost drowned. The fool, “Those little ducks were
able to cross here; why couldn’t a big fellow like you?” Wesselski Bebel II 146
No. 146.
A dog has eaten 14 pounds of butter; the fool squeezes 16 pounds from him. Fb “sm[ö]r” III 412b.

Fool cuts off tails of oxen so that they will look like
fine steeds.
Ignorant bride castrates groom when jokingly told to do so.
Nun tells friar to get rid of offending member.
He does so. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Fool undergoes castration to put on weight.

Simpleton‘s ignorance of anatomy leads him to share his
wife with a priest.

Fool believes that he has begot child with his sister by an
earbox.

The man without a member: foolish wife gives her husband
money to buy himself one.

Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. *2911; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 1543*.

Cowboy shoots his wife when she breaks her leg (or is injured
in another way).

content:
Blamed for not teaching calf better. Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin I 236 No. 108.
child:
Man beats calves because the bull has butted him over the
fence.
Wolf punished for his father’s misdeeds.

content: The ass deprived of his saddle.

A man’s coat is stolen when he leaves his ass for a
moment. He takes the saddle off the ass and says that he will give it back if
the ass will return the coat. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin *223 No. 61.

In a land where the sickle is not known the new sickle
cuts off the head of a man. It is drowned. *Type 1202.
child: Sickle punished by being tied in top of a tree.

The men hang themselves in the attempt. Cheremis:
Sebeok-Nyerges.

content:
On
a rainy day when shot will not go a man flogs the shot. It goes and he shoots a
deer. Africa (Vai): Ellis 189 No. 4.
Man punishes offending part of his body.
child: Man beats his foot for slipping.

content: Man avenges self on animals by wholesale slaughter.
child:
Man avenges brother‘s death by wholesale slaughter of wild
pigs.
Numskull does not understand about baby’s skull.

Sticks needle through it. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II
215 No. 445; Spanish: Espinosa III 147; West Indies: Flowers 486.
Foolish mother does not understand how babies cry.

Wrings the child‘s neck. Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and
Dale II 406 No. 3.

content: Horse taught to live without food.

Dies. Type 1682; Wienert FFC LVI 72 (ET 364), 129 (ST
370); Halm Aesop No. 176.
child:
Fails in the war. Wienert FFC LVI 72 (ET 363), 129 (ST 369); Halm Aesop No.
178.
Three brothers take turns using mule.

None of them feeds him, supposing that the others have.
The mule dies. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 575.

content:
Fool carries wife across stream head downwards and drowns
her.

Scholar speaks Latin on hunt so that the birds cannot
understand him.

Woman thinks calf‘s bleating has accused her of stealing
from harvest.

Begs that people not believe what calf said. (Cf. †N611.) India:
Thompson-Balys.
Objects supposed to be born, grow, and die like animals.

child:
A man has drunk so much of various wines that he is sick.
He says to the wines, “Have peace among yourselves and don’t quarrel or I‘ll
throw you out the window.” *Wesselski Bebel II 102 No. 14.

On his deathbed refuses to forgive nails which ruined his
tools. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 702.

Sea says that it is calm itself, but the wind blew it up
and broke the ship. Wienert FFC LVI 75 (ET 406), 123 (ST 317); Halm Aesop No.
94.

content:
A boy recently home from school sees his mother trying to
catch the cock. “Don‘t mother, don’t break his freedom or we will suffer for
it.” Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 817.

Absurd attempt to punish sea. Indonesia: DeVries‘s list
No. 254. Cf. Yeats’s “Cuchulain‘s Fight with the Sea.”
Tree-trunks laid crosswise of the sledge.

In a storm on the ice, numskulls stick needles into the ice to keep from
blowing away. Type 1279.

But the man who uses the crowbar is to blame for the
downfall of the wall. Wienert FFC LVI 75 (ET 400), 123 (ST 319); Halm Aesop No.
402.

He comes to a stream but not wishing to get his feet wet
he sits down to wait for the stream to run down. He helps to bale the stream
out with a hazelnut shell and keeps it up for months. Italian: Gonzenbach No.
17, Italian Novella: Rotunda.
White sheep-skin used as a source of light.
child: Trying to catch light in a mouse-trap.

content:
An old woman who has forgotten to knead it in the dough
throws it into the stove. Type 1261*.
The fool puts but one stick of wood in the stove.
Wants the organ to come and play for her.

An old woman enraptured with the sound of a cathedral
organ prays for it to come to her house and gives it directions as to where she
lives. Bolte Frey 235 No. 54.

Fools chain a wheelbarrow, bitten by a mad dog, lest it bite others. Field Pent
Cuckoo 15.

Fool
puts black clothes on his hen‘s necks. He tells people that they mourn their
mother. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 210 No. 19.

A boy roasts snails and they make noise in cooking. “Wretches, your house burns
and yet you sing!” Wienert FFC LVI 65 (ET 291), 135 (ST 413); Halm Aesop No.
214.

The woman tries to tire out her rival’s boat so as to win the race, but only
tires herself. Type 1277; Christensen DF XLVII 190.
Trickster joins bulrushes in a dance.

He thinks they are dancing when he sees them waving. N. A.
Indian: *Thompson Tales 306 n. 109dd.
child: Simpleton addresses a field of reeds.

Fool believes they can be taught. *Type 1750; Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 843.

Fool
made to believe that his ass (ox) has been educated and has become mayor. *Type
1675; *BP I 59; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 224 No. 63; *Fb “tyr” III 908b;
Christensen DF XLVII 229; England: Baughman; India: *Thompson-Balys.

content: Animal or object expected to go alone.
child: Object sent to go by itself.
Cheeses thrown down to find their way home.

Numskull lets one roll down hill; sends the other to bring
it back. *Type 1291; BP I 521.
Three-legged pot sent to walk home.
Table thrown out of the sledge; to go home by itself.
Spinning wheel is sent home by itself.

The man asks his wife if it has arrived before him, finds
that it has not. “I thought not. I came a shorter way.” Scotland: *Baughman.
Sickle laid in field and told to cut grain.
Fool sends letter home by a flooded river.
Animal sent to go by itself.
Ass loaded and commanded to go home.

*Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 272 No. 281; Spanish:
Espinosa III 147.

Since he is a swift runner they expect it to reach the
landlord in time. Field Pent Cuckoo 6; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Fishes to stop at his house.

Fool directs them as he places them in stream. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content:
An ox strays on the rascal‘s land but escapes from him.
The next week he sees the ox yoked up and gives him a beating. The master is
astonished. The rascal: “Let me alone; he knows well enough what he has done.”
Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 210 No. 20.
Mouth and ears stopped up lest wisdom escape.

Numskulls are affected by heat from stove which has no fire
in it.

Fool tries to purify cotton by burning it (as the goldsmith
does with gold).
Tree pulled down in order to give it water to drink.
Stupid woman swims on the roof.
Fools try to use buffalo tongue as a knife.
Man made to believe that he is someone else.
child: White man made to believe that he is a negro.

Sleeps with a negro. His friends blacken him during the
night. When he is waked up, he complains that they have waked the wrong man.
Clouston Noodles 7; L. Schmidt Oesterr. Zs. f. Vksk. 1954, 130; England, U.S.:
Baughman.
Man made to believe that he is a dog.

He barks at people.
*Type 1406; Bédier Fabliaux 265ff.; *Crane Vitry 227 No. 231.

A numskull ties a pumpkin to his leg at night so that he
shall know himself in the morning. Someone ties the pumpkin to another’s leg
and the numskull is not sure of his identity next morning. Clouston Noodles 7.
Numskull made to believe he is an evil spirit.

content:
Fb “selv”; L. Schmidt Oesterr. Zs f. Vksk. 1954, 129ff.;
India: *Thompson-Balys.
child: Numskull‘s beard cut off: does not know himself.

*Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 274 No. 298; Christensen DF
XLVII 27, 221 No. 83; India: Thompson-Balys.
Woman’s garments cut off: does not know herself.

*Type 1383; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 274 No. 298;
Christensen DF XLVII 35.
Woman in tar and feathers does not know herself.

*Type 1383; Fb “tjære” III 811a; Christensen DF
XLVII 35; India: Thompson-Balys.
Fool in new clothes does not know himself.

Wesselski Mönchslatein
193 No. 152; Christensen DF XLVII 221 No. 83.
Man does not know himself from another identically clad.
Fool at baths believes he is someone else.

Sees everybody naked. Puts straw on his shoulder to
identify himself. Straw floats to another bather. “You are me and I am you!”
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content:
Three wishes will be granted: used up
foolishly. *Bédier Fabliaux 212ff., 471; Type 750; *Bolte Zs. f. vgl. Litgsch.
VII 453; *BP II 212; *Fb “[ö]nske” III 1179a. -- Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. “souhaits”; Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys;
Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 213, Coster-Wijsman 46 No. 56.
Things thought at night to be other frightful object.
child: Windmill thought to be holy cross (church, God).

Type 1322**; Christensen DF XLVII 212 No. 68; Russian:
Andrejev 1322**; India: Thompson-Balys.
Clock ticking thought to be gnawing of mice.

content: Objects thought to be the devil.
child: Steamship thought to be the devil.
Watch mistaken for the devil‘s eye.

Knocked to pieces. Type 1321*; Christensen DF XLVII 187;
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1679*.
Glowing wheel supposed to be the devil.
Robber or dog in church thought to be a ghost.
Cows in church thought to be ghost.
Dropping dough thought to be a ghost.

It drops on the floor and the man thinks the place is
haunted. Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 137 No. 101; Finnish: Aarne FFC XXXIII 47 No.
101.

Sound of water dripping on dinner pail thought to be ghost
using pick in mine.
Noise in house thought to be ghost.

Man sleeping in stable (abandoned cabin) thinks entering
animals are ghosts: kills them.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3445, Legends Nos. 872ff.; U.S.: Baughman.
Animal with lighted candle thought to be ghost.
Person in white thought to be ghost.
Sleep-walker thought to be a ghost until discovered.

Person in haunted house shoots off all his toes thinking
they are ghosts.
Butter cask thought to be a dead man.
Fools knock it in two. Type 1314.

content: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3446, Legends Nos. 875-885.
child: Laughter of boy thought to be spirits’ laughter.

content: Animals thought to be the devils or ghosts.
child: Grasshopper thought to be the devil.
Crab thought to be the devil.
Ass thought to be the devil.

Man sees Hereford cow at night; thinks it is devil, says,
“Devil I deny thee! I am a psalmsinger and a worshiper of God!” England:
Baughman.

Man addresses colt: “Abide, Satan! I am a righteous man and
a psalm singer.”

Fool in the dark mistakes cat‘s eyes for embers. Is attacked by the cat and he
thinks it is the devil. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Fox in coffer thought to be devil.
Black sheep thought to be the devil.

content: Man thought to be a devil or ghost.
child: Man costumed as demon thought to be devil; thieves flee.
Woman thought to be devil; thieves flee.
Man mistaken for Famine and Cholera in person.

Priest exorcising demon mistaken for demon and beaten to
death.
Man thought to be devil by lion.

Men, on first seeing wives with hair, think they are
witches and run away.
Lion thinks man astride him is monster: frightened.

Man reported to be dead so that people flee from him as
from a ghost.

content:
On the way home from
town he destroys his purchases. (Cf. †J1851, †J1856, †J1871.) Lithuanian: Balys
Index No. 1677*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1681 I*; Prussian: Plenzat 75.

child: Old woman‘s sneeze mistaken for gunfire.

content: Sweeping with a stick instead of a broom.

Köhler-Bolte Zs. f.
Vksk. VI 63 (to Gonzenbach No. 13).
Jumping into the river after their comrade.

Through misunderstanding one of the men jumps into the
river. He calls out; the others think that he wants them to follow, and all jump
in and are drowned. *BP II 556 n. 1; Japanese: Ikeda.
Did the calf eat the man?

A fool, liking the shoes on the feet of a man hanged on a gallows, cuts
off the swollen feet in order to carry off the shoes. In the room in which he
sleeps that night is a newborn calf. The next morning the man takes the shoes
but leaves the feet. Peasants agree that the calf has eaten the man all but the
feet. They burn the house to destroy the calf. Type 1281; *Wesselski Bebel I
231 No. 144; Danish: Christensen DF L 65, Nyrop Dania I (1890) 283ff., cf. II
68ff.; U.S.: Baughman.

Fool thinks gold is being destroyed when snails crawl over
it.

A landlord in anger throws a dish out the window. The
numskull throws the rest out, thinking that the landlord wanted to eat
outdoors. *Wesselski Bebel I 194 No. 65.
Fool not recognizing coins lying on roadside leaves them.

child: Owl’s hoot misunderstood by lost simpleton.
*Wesselski Bebel II 158 No. 183. Cf. BP II 535.

The old maid answers the owl‘s hoot, saying “Anybody,
Lord!” or giving the name of the young man she wants.
Turkey‘s gobble misunderstood by man lost in woods.

Hears a rooster crow, saying: “Cocky kuko! It‘s the same
everywhere!” He returns home. England, U.S.: *Baughman.
Seeds rattling in pods thought to be insults.
Rabbits think sound of waves is great danger to them.

.” The rain drops: “Here he is..” The little bell: “He is
hiding here..” Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1264*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1264
I*.
Hissing of fire thought to be noise of cooking muffins.

Hunchback springs into it to burn to his death. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Numskull thief thinks snoring sleeper is asking for food.

Fool kills his wife because he thinks that she has eaten
part of them. Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 412 No. 11.
Boiling milk thought to be overflowing.
Simpleton lets it run over. Type 1328*.
Numskull thinks his prayers have stopped milk boiling over.

Actually his wife has added cold water. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Boiling pumpkin thought to be talking.
Boiling pot on the floor thought to be self-cooking.
Christensen DF XLVII 177 No. 5, cf. 192 No. 18.
Fish dancing about in cooking pot appears to be many.
Cook eats one; none left. India: Thompson-Balys.

Handful of black pepper taken into mouth instead of cooking
it in food.

The
peasant entertains a priest at tea. Making it, puts in all the tea, six pounds
of sugar, a piece of bacon, etc. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2439*; Russian:
Andrejev No. 1710*.

Small boy is at home to watch the dinner. Runs into
church, calls out to his mother that the sheep‘s head has eaten all the
dumplings (or butted them out of the pot). England, U.S.: *Baughman.
All the beans cooked for one meal.
Stupid servant cooks all the rice for one meal.
Numskull thinks boiling pot is threatening him: breaks pot.

content: Man thinks own toe is snake‘s head and cuts it off.

child: Urination of bull thought to be bleeding.
Fools think thorn bush doesn’t sting at night.

Simpleton sleeping in cold room breaks window to let the
cold out.

Fool wakes with sleeping mat over head and thinks it is
still night.
Story told about a deer: fool starts chase.
Jackdaw tries to swallow sparks from glowworm.
Numskull strikes all matches in order to try them.

Foolish soldier at guard by cannon therefore quits. Christensen DF XLVII no.
49.

Scotsman thinks moose is a mouse, asks what rats look like
in this country.
Hunter mistakes louse on his eyelash for game.

He shoots several times before he notices the trouble.
U.S.: *Baughman.

Numskull thinks fireflies are mosquitoes carrying lanterns
to find victims.

content: Tiger (lion, etc.) mistaken for domestic animal.
child:
Fool trying to steal goat in dark catches thieving tiger. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Fool rides tiger thinking it to be a big male-goat.
Lion thought to be donkey: drunkard rides it.

Stupid husband mistakes tiger-cubs for jungle cats despite
wife’s judgment.

content: Rabbit thought to be a cow.

Servant sent to bring in cows is found chasing rabbits. BP
III 260 (Grimm No. 162); U.S.: Baughman.
Other animals thought to be a giant cat.

Hero in search of monster brings home a dog, zebra, etc.
thinking it is the animal he seeks. Zanzibar: Bateman 160 No. 8.
Earthworm thought to be snake (or other monster).
In the man‘s absence eats the mare. *Type 1311.

“I know you well enough, you have put on a blue coat.”
Type 1317*.
Numskull stays till he has finished.

As he is making water he hears a brook flowing and
mistakes what it is. He waits for a day and a half. *Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin I 210 No. 23; U.S.: Baughman.

child: Numskull thinks his shadow is a man pursuing him.
Shadow mistaken for thief: is beaten.

Monkey seeing tiger attack his shadow is frightened so that
he falls from tree.

content: Numskull thinks the bishop‘s snoring is his death rattle.

He strikes at a fly on the bishop’s nose because it seems
to be killing the bishop. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 712.
child:
Numskull shoots grasshopper which lighted on the shoulder
of his friend and kills friend.

Boy strikes at a fly on his sister’s breast: it turns into
nipple and girl thinks it due to brother‘s caress.

One man strikes at partridge which has lighted on second
man’s head.

content:
Jacobs Aesop 204 No. 20; Wienert FFC LVI 75 (ET 405), 124 (ST 333); Halm Aesop
No. 47.
One object thought to be another.
child: Pumpkin thought to be an ass‘s egg.
Boy thinks terrapin hatches from bedbug eggs.

Small boy examines bedbug eggs under pillow every morning.
One morning he finds a terrapin there. “I don‘t see how we raised this so
quick.” U.S.: Baughman.

Potatoes mistaken for “irregular eggs”, or “eggs of the
earth.”
Dog mistakes mussel for an egg.

Cuts his mouth. Wienert FFC LVI 63 (ET 268), 107 (ST 199);
Halm Aesop No. 223.
Coins thought to be red beans.
Coins thought to be uncooked cakes.
Culture hero’s pubic hair thought to be bear hair.

N. A. Indian (Peoria, Kickapoo, Potawatomi): Michelson
JAFL XXX 494.

Pubic hair of ardent husband‘s wife thought to be calf’s
tail by peasant in tree.
Man puts food bowl on head thinking it a helmet.
Fish bones in soup thought to be underdone peas.
Fools think evening star is morning star.

Start morning journey evening before. India:
Thompson-Balys.

Cotton pods knocked off by bullock thought to be lumps of
bullock‘s fat.
Excrements thought to be meat and therefore eaten.
Christensen DF XLVII 192 No. 18; India: Thompson-Balys.
Numskull tries to sell it. Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.

Gun thought to be clarinet: one man blows, another presses
the “keys”.
Foolish tiger thinks dog’s tail is a gun.
Frog thinks cattle are distant country.

Eight-oared ferry-boat mistaken for an animal which must
have long legs to wade the stream.

content:
Reflection in water thought to be the original of the thing
reflected.
child:
The numskull sees a cow drink from a pool where the moon is
reflected. The moon goes under a cloud. He thinks the cow has eaten the moon
and slaughters her to recover it. Type 1335; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 241
No. 124; *Köhler-Bolte I 90, 498; Christensen DF XLVII 181.

A
numskull sees the moon in the water and throws a rope in to rescue it, but
falls in himself. He sees the moon in the sky. At least the moon was saved!
*Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 241 No. 124; Christensen DF XLVII 217--18 no.
78; American Negro: Harris Nights 100 No. 19.
Wolf tries to drink well dry to get cheese.

Dogs by river try to get food in river by drinking the
river dry.

Wienert FFC LVI 62 (ET 246),
119 (ST 287); Halm Aesop No. 218.

Demon tries to recover object from river by drinking it
dry.
Moon‘s reflection thought to be gold in water.
Fools dive for it. India: Thompson-Balys.
Jackals jump into well after drums and are killed.
Dog drops his meat for the reflection.

Crossing a stream with
meat in his mouth he sees his reflection; thinking it another dog with meat he
dives for it and loses his meat. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 426; *Chauvin II 85;
B[ö]dker Exempler 275 No. 13; Wienert FFC LVI 64 (ET 270), *105 (ST 178); Halm
Aesop No. 233; *Crane Vitry 140 No. 18; Scala Celi 19a No. 111; Jacobs Aesop
199 No. 3.--Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Zulu):
Callaway 357 (cf. †J1791.3).

India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian:
*Thompson Tales 352 n. 270a.
Shooting at enemy’s reflection in water.
Man throws stone at own reflection in water.
Frog leaps into water after elephant‘s reflection.
Diving for reflection of beautiful woman.

Indonesian, Melanesian: Dixon 227 n. 34; N. A. Indian:
*Thompson Tales 352 n. 270b.

Woman dives in water three times after reflected image of
man peering down from a tree.

Ugly woman sees beautiful woman reflected in water and
thinks it is herself.
Ogre sees beautiful woman reflected in water.

Attempts to drink the
lake dry. (Cf. †J1791.3.1.) Type 1141*; Japanese: Ikeda.
Man does not recognize his own reflection in the water.

*Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 276 No. 311; Penzer VI
86f.; India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 17; Hawaii: Beckwith
Myth 441; American Negro: Harris Remus 68 No. 14.

Simpleton thinks his reflection in jar of melted butter is
thief;

strikes at the jar and breaks it.
India: Thompson-Balys.
Goose dives for star, thinking it a fish.

The next day when she
sees fish, she lets it escape. Chauvin II 89 No. 28; B[ö]dker Exempler 284 No.
30; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Fools see bee‘s nest reflected in water: try to carry off
the well.
Fool sees golden-crested bird reflected in water.
Thinks it is gold. Penzer V 115 n. 1.

Meantime rascal steals the fruit itself. Spanish: Espinosa
III 206f.; Indonesia: Coster-Wijsman 37 No. 25.

Elephant frightened at agitated reflection of moon in
water.

content: Numskulls lose corpse and bury live person instead.

child: Men build hedge to keep in the moonlight.

content: Image in mirror mistaken for picture.
child:
Foolish demon sees his reflection in trickster’s mirror and
is convinced he has been captured.

content: Animal thought to be a person.
child:
In a ghost house he is thought to be a tailor who snips
the devil with his scissors. *Fb “gås” I 528b.
Bear on haywagon (on horse) thought to be the preacher.
The bear mistaken for a saint.
Crab caught on tiger‘s tail thought to be pursuing man.
Deer thought to be man with basket on head.
Dressed up monkey thought to be a nobleman.

The strong man meets a bear in the forest, takes it for a
German and struggles with it. Having strangled the bear, fears he has killed a
man. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1283*.
Foolish wife believes goats’ heads are human heads.

content: Fool thinks belly is speaking to him; stabs himself.

Other animals are shouting at him. Indonesia: DeVries’s
list No. 78.

child: Dove sees painted cups of water and dashes into them.

Wienert FFC LVI 64 (ET 276), 107 (ST 196); Halm Aesop No.
357.

Numskull (female devil) thinks her pubic hair has been
telling her lies and pulls it out together with the skin.
Fool cannot answer as his mouth is full;

thought to have an
abscess in cheeks, allows them to be cut open. India: Thompson-Balys. (Cf.
†W111.5.8.)

Bird protruding from king’s stomach cut out with swords:
king killed.
Child‘s stomach split open to cure him of wandering.

content:
Christensen DF XLVII 176, 196; American Negro: Harris
Nights 230 No. 39, Work JAFL XXXII 403, Parsons MAFLS XVI 32.

child: Similar sounding words mistaken for each other.

Word for wife is similar, so wife is covered. India:
Thompson-Balys.

Daughter says “Sobur” (wait) to her father when he asks
what to bring from the journey.

Father
finds Prince Sobur. India: Thompson-Balys.

Numskull referring to a forgotten name keeps saying “I have
lost it.”

People dive into tank to recover
treasure they think he has lost. India: Thompson-Balys.

A fool given money to buy something to eat; goes around
asking for a thing called “something.”

content: Conversation by sign language mutually misunderstood.

child:
A cleric is asked whether he is of legitimate birth (“de legitimo thoro”). “No,
I am not from that place; I am from Schmich.” *Wesselski Bebel II 126 No. 80.

content: Words in a foreign language thought to be insults.
child:
Foreigner asks who owns property, clothing, servants; whose wife an attractive
woman is; whose funeral is in progress? Answer to each question is “I don’t
understand,” which foreigner takes to be a person‘s name. (Cf. †J1152,
†J1741, †X111.7.) Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. III (N.F.) 173-8.

content: Breath in the cold thought to be tobacco smoke.

Makes ridiculous report to his king. Bolte Frey‘s
Gartengesellschaft 217 No. 5.
child: Christian laws are profitless, Turkish ambassador says.

Good people do not need them; bad people do not reform as
a result of them. Spanish: Childers.

content:
Numskull
refuses communion because his sister died shortly after eating the bread.
*Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 572.

A pope in writing to a king says, “To our dear son Frederick.” Upon
hearing this the fool cries out, “That is a lie; he is no priest‘s son. I knew
his father and mother and they were both honest people.” *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
51.
The falcon not so good as represented.

A nobleman praises his falcon. His fool, supposing they
were praising the falcon as food, kills the bird, but is disappointed in the
taste. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 52; *Wesselski Bebel I 194 No. 64; Alphabet No.
239.

Peasants go to visit the
sea. They see a waving flax-field, and, thinking it is the sea, jump in to
swim. *Type 1290; *BP III 205; Köhler-Bolte I 112; Christensen DF XLVII 195 no.
20; Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. “lin”, “pêche”; India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Trying to swim in the mist.

content:
Misunderstanding of church customs or ceremonies causes
inappropriate action.
child: Christ accused of trying to fool the people.

Fool sees the image of Christ elevated on Ascension Day to
the beams of the church. He accuses Christ of having fooled the people into
believing that he has gone to heaven. Wesselski Bebel II 158 No. 181.
Christ’s image has broken his arm.

A man refuses to have anything to do with the crucifix
because once an image of Christ has fallen on him in church and broken his arm.
Reminded that this image is not the same, he replies that it is the son of the
other and is just as bad. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 270.

Maidservant on way to church on Palm Sunday meets priests leading ass on which
Jesus rode. The maid runs home and tells her mistress that the Lord has mounted
and has just gone away. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 865.
Numskull knocks the figure of Jesus from the ass.
Bishop struck for breaking the peace.

At a wedding after a period of silent prayer the bishop
begins an antiphony. The fools walks up and strikes the bishop: “You have made
this shouting in the church.” Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 49.

Numskull thinks the extinguishing of lights at the church
presages a fight.

Move away from Moslem land so that Allah need not be
feared.
Big tree thought to be snake.
Killed with guns and spears. Type 1315.
Old sausage (roll) taken for frightening animal.
Object thought to be a turkey.
Island thought to be large dog.

content:
The delegate slips and falls, cursing: “The devil may take
you!” The serfs outside think this was the congratulation, and all cry in
chorus: “You and your family!” Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *1708; Rumanian:
Schullerus FFC LXXVIII 98 No. 14.

child: Giant thought to be a hill.
Dead man is thought to be alive.

Man with abhorrence for
corpse sleeps with one thinking it alive. (Cf. †H1410.) Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Fool lays his hand on demon in the dark, believing it is
male goat he has come to steal.

content:
A
fool sees a boat (with rowers) obedient to commands, “Right! Left!” etc. He
asks what kind of wood the boat is made of. Later he gets a log of that wood
and tries to make it obey commands. Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 258.

Goat chewing cud angers fool, who thinks goat is mimicking
him.
Person thought to be an object.
child: Small priest covered with large hat thought to be a hat.
Sleeping soldier thought to be recumbent statue in chapel.
Turtle thought to be an island.
White mare thought to be church.
Glowworm thought to be a fire.
Fish thought to be chewed sugar-cane.

Numskulls therefore throw away their fish. Indonesian:
DeVries‘s list No. 262.
Wolf thought to be log of wood.

Bites tiger who tries to play flute. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Snake mistaken for a whip by a blind man.

Living toad or beetles thought to be lost food and
therefore eaten by numskulls.
Man mistakes dragon for log, sits on it.
Bear mistaken for a floating log (blanket).

Four blind men feel an elephant’s leg, tail, ear and body, respectively, and
conclude it is like a log, a rope, a fan, and something without beginning or
end. *Taylor English Riddles in Oral Tradition (Berkeley, 1951) 582 n. 11;
India: Thompson-Balys.
Fool mistakes dung-beetles for fruit: eats them.
Horsemen thought to be men mounted on cattle.

content: Disastrous jump to retrieve lost object.
child: Miser jumps into a ravine to retrieve single grain.

Man leaps into river and drowns in effort to save his
treasure.

content:
Foolish interference in quarrel of the strong fatal to the
weak.
child:
Sparrow intervenes in quarrel between elephants: crushed to
death.
Quarrel and fight over details of air-castles.

*Type 1430; BP III 275; *Gerould MLN XIX 228; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Arab: Azov JPASB (n.s.) II 402f.; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list
No. 269, Coster-Wijsman 65f. Nos. 107--110.

Man plants hedge: sheep will leave wool on the thorns and
bring riches.

To build a palace in the sky: hawk as architect is let fly
in the air.

Fools cast lots for royal purple of queen who is still
alive.

content: Air-castle shattered by lack of forethought.
child: Air-castle: the jar of honey to be sold.

In his excitement he
breaks the jar. *BP III 261f.; *Chauvin II 101 No. 60; *Gerould MLN XIX 229; B[ö]dker
Exempler 300 No. 65; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella; *Rotunda;
Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas IV 55, 277; India: *Thompson-Balys.
Air-castle: basket of glassware to be sold.
In his excitement he breaks the glassware. BP III 264.
Air-castle: basket of eggs to be sold.
Pot of flour to be sold: broken.
Air-castle: jar of oil to be sold.
Air-castle: pail of milk to be sold.
Air-castles: pail of milk to be sold.

Old woman thinks about the horse she is finally to get
from the sale. In her imagination she spurs it and spills the milk. *Gerould
MLN XIX 225.
Air-castle: to sell hide of sleeping deer.

In his excitement he wakes the deer, who runs off. *BP III
265.
Toad having found money daydreams and is run over.
Which way the sheep shall return.

One man plans to buy sheep; another says that he shall not
drive them across the bridge. They quarrel over the sheep, which have not yet
been acquired. A third numskull to convince them of their foolishness pours all
his meal out in the water so as to show them the empty sack. “How much meal is
in the sack?” he asks. “None.” “There is just that much wit in your heads.”
*Clouston Noodles 26; Field Pent Cuckoo 2; England: Baughman.
Foolish logician upsets ghee in argument.

“Does the ghee protect the saucer, or the saucer the
ghee?” India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Distress over imagined troubles of unborn child.

(Clever Else.) Girl sent to cellar to get wine to serve
the suitor begins weeping over the troubles of the child which she might have
if she married the suitor. Her parents join her. Meanwhile the suitor leaves.
*Type 1450; *BP I 335; *Clouston Noodles 191; Christensen DF L 35; Jewish: bin
Gorion Born Judas IV 55, 277; India: Thompson-Balys; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS
XVII 285 No. 125.
child:
Queen grieves herself to death over fate of her children
after her death.

content: Servant plans to deceive his master by refusing to eat.

child:
The hungry fox waits in vain for horse‘s scrotum (lips) to
fall off.
The daw waits in vain for the figs to ripen in winter.
Men (animals) wait in vain for nuts to fall from a tree.

Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 410 No. 8;
American Negro: Harris Nights 223 No. 38.

Waiting in vain for fruit to fall from a non-fruitbearing
tree.

Wolf scorns salt meat (etc.) in false expectation of other
booty.
Wesselski Märchen 250 No. 58; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 3.
Wolf waits in vain for the nurse to throw away the child.
Dog waits to be hit with meat.

A butcher has threatened to hit him with a piece of meat.
Chauvin III 57 No. 16.
Dog follows washerwoman with bundle hoping for meat.

Dupe waits for rear wheels of wagon to overtake front
wheels.

Is told that money is thus made.
England, U.S.: Baughman; American Negro: Harris Friends 122 No. 16.
Hare waits in vain for leaves to fall from palm tree.
Hare waits in vain for man’s hand to fall off.
He sees it dangling. India: Thompson-Balys.
Sacrifice of one son to get another.

A woman plans to sacrifice her only son so that the gods
will permit her to give birth to another son. Penzer V 94.

content: Loss of eating contest because of weak legs.

The sheep thinks that that is the reason for loss of the
contest. Type 203*; Russian: Andrejev No. 203.
Learn to swim before going into the water.

The
queen has been told that the peasants have no bread. Type 1446*; Bolte Montanus
601 No. 48.
child:
King ignorant of famine says the people can live on pulse
(sugar) and rice.

content: Taking the seed out at night.

Numskull plants seed in daytime and takes it out at night.
”Man must guard his treasures“ (or ”Growing in the daytime is enough“).
Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 245 No. 139.
Three reasons for not giving alms.

(1) Student has only one eye: Aristotle says to beware of
those whom nature has marked. (2) Student comes from Bremen: no one of
consequence comes from there. (3) His name is Nicholas: no one with that name
can succeed. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 611; cf. Type 1661.
The inconvenience of having a father:

The numskull to his father: ”If you had never been born I
would get my grandfather‘s estate.“ Clouston Noodles 4.

The fool lies still as the thief enters the
house, hoping that the thief may find something so that he can take it back
from the thief. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 231 No. 83, Mönchslatein 170 No.
134.
child:
Robbed man blames thief for not warning him so that he
could have witnesses to the theft.

content:
A
rustic refuses to believe reports about hell from a priest who has not been
there. Herbert III 82.
Climb down as you climb up.

A peasant falls out of a tree. A neighbor advises him not
to climb trees. Another suggests that he always climb down a tree with the same
skill and rapidity that he climbed up. Bolte Frey 222 No. 18; Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Fool tastes every piece of fruit before giving it to his master. Penzer V 94;
Chauvin VII 115.

As the fool starts for the doctor the wife changes her
mind. He continues to the doctor so as to tell him about it and to say that now
he need not come. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 233 No. 456.
child: Useless trip to find a name the wife already knew.

Fool goes to astrologer for child‘s name, but forgets it
on way home. Later wife happens to use the word and reminds him. But he cannot
see the use of the trip when she already knew this word. India: Thompson-Balys.
Servant sent to doctor finds trip futile.

Doctor may not be in and, if he is there, he may not give
the medicine. He may give the medicine but it may not have any effect; or, if
it does have any, he has to die someday anyway and the medicine will not
prevent him from dying. India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
A man who is away from home writes a letter to his wife but can find no
messenger. He delivers the letter himself and then goes on back to where he has
been. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 233 No. 456.
child: Scribe cannot write a letter because he has bad leg.

Must carry letter in person since no one else can read it.
India: Thompson-Balys.
Fool writes letter very slowly: recipient cannot read fast.

content: Fool sleeps so as to avoid idleness.

child: Each of two persons wants to sleep in the middle.

(Sometimes solved by placing an object on one side of the
bed.) Type 1289; Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 416 No. 15.

A profitable fight: three for one! A priest boasts of his
profitable fight with the peasants, where he has received three blows for every
one given.

Fool regrets that he had
not eaten number seven first since that was the one that brought satisfaction.
*Von der Leyen Das Märchen 78 and Herrigs Archiv CXIV 20 n. 2; India:
Thompson-Balys.
If the horse can pull one load he can pull two.

A numskull is asked how many daily prayers (Moslem) there are.
“Twenty.”--“There are only four.”--“I said that there are twenty; that is even
better.” *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 261 No. 222.

Numskull asked the number of commandments replies that
there are twenty. He explains to another that he knows there must be more than
twenty because the minister would not accept his answer. Scotland: Baughman.
Selling his half of the house.

A man owns half a house. He wants to sell his half so as
to get money to buy the other half and thus have a whole house. Wesselski
Hodscha Nasreddin I 282 No. 336.

Dentist duped to pull out two teeth for one because of the
expensiveness.

Man prefers small oysters, since he will get more to the
hundred.

Numskull finds that one feather makes a hard pillow, thinks
a sackful would be unbearable.

content: Effects of age and size absurdly applied.
child:
Two fifteen-year old slaves ordered: fool brings one thirty
years old.

Priest to have maid at least fifty years old: gets one aged
twenty and one aged thirty.
Burial in old grave to deceive angel.

Fool thinks that the angel who comes to question him will
pass him by since he has apparently been dead a long time. Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin
I 210 No. 22.
