Birds flee from cuckoo who, they believe, will later become
a hawk.

Wienert FFC LVI 55 (ET 149), 119
(ST 290); Halm Aesop No. 198.

content: Kindness unwise when it imperils one’s food supply.
child: Eagle warns shepherds that wolf is eating sheep.

Crow rebukes eagle for thus imperiling his own food
supply. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 36 No. 229*.
The only person in the bath.

Servant reports to master that there is but one person in
the public bath Master finds three hundred. Only one person had removed stone
from his path; rest had stubbed toes. He was only one worthy of the name of
man. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 604.

content:
Crab takes hold of heron‘s neck and fearing attack cuts
neck and kills him.

J751. †J751. Consider
difficulties of course you are about to undertake.
child:
Servant about to be caught for theft
rehearses the lie he is to tell his master. He finds lies so transparent that
he decides to tell the truth. Wesselski Märchen 200.
Lady answers queen so straightforwardly she gets light punishment.

content: Old age must be planned for.
child: Child finds gray hair in wicked father‘s head.

Father sees that it is time for him to reform. Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 292.

Miller has four horses to carry grain. He uses only one,
so that it soon dies. Four horses are childhood, youth, manhood, and old age.
Don’t heap all burden of securing salvation on the fourth horse, old age. Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 291.

Charges a pair of shoes to consort with men. When old she
pays with shoes the men who will consort with her. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

King to avoid possible assassination singes his beard
rather than have barber shave him.

King to avoid possible assassination has queen’s quarters
searched before he enters.
Doctor gives advice after patient dies.

Scorned for lack of foresight. Wienert FFC LVI *84 (ET
509), 108 (ST 204); Halm Aesop No. 169.

content: All aspects of a plan must be foreseen.
child:
Man allowed to manage the weather forgets to ask help of the wind. All goes
wrong and he must give up management. *Type 752B; *Fb “vind” III 1059a.

content: Defences in and out of season.
child: Wild-boar sharpens tusks when no enemy is in sight.

Tells fox that when enemy comes there are other things to
do. Wienert FFC LVI 61 (ET 237), 108 (ST 203); Halm Aesop No. 407.

Man decides to make himself strong in peaceful times rather
than wait until attacked.

content: Do not work yourself out of employment.
child:
if she killed them she would no longer have employment.
India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
Foolishness of king‘s taking a washerman for chief
minister;

washerman makes no preparation
for war and kingdom is conquered. India: Thompson-Balys.

child:
Mice
decide that a bell should be put on the cat but can find no one to tie it on
her. *Type 110; Wienert FFC LVI 53 (ET 128), 96 (ST 97); Halm Aesop No. 15;
Jacobs Aesop 216 No. 67; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 260 No. 213, *Arlotto
II 226 No. 93; *Baum MLN XXXIV (1919) 462; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 634; Dh IV
145ff.; Herbert III 36ff. -- Spanish Exempla: Keller; American Negro: Harris
Nights 311 No. 53.

content: In time of plenty provide for want.
child:
Lazy bird is put to shame by thrift of industrious bird.
In winter he is in distress. *Type 249; *Chauvin III 58 No. 19; Wienert FFC LVI
55 (ET 156, 157), 126 (ST 347); Halm Aesop No. 295, 401; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
845; Jacobs Aesop 208 No. 36.--Italian Novella: Rotunda; N. A. Indian: Thompson
CColl II 451.
Improvident mouse eats grain stored for famine.

Loss is discovered and grain placed elsewhere. Mouse, who
has saved nothing, starves. *Chauvin II 115 No. 90.
King for a year provides for future.

Knowing that the custom is that he is to be deposed in a
year, he sends provisions to a safe place out of the kingdom. *Crane Vitry 137
No. 9; Herbert III 63, 191; Oesterley Gesta Romanorum No. 224; *Chauvin II 160
No. 49, 192 No. 9, III 101 No. 8; Scala Celi No. 134; Alphabet No.
655.--Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas IV 36, 275f.
Wise man stores grain against coming famine.
Industrious ant works always at his harvest to keep it dry.

Ant brings stored grain out into sun to keep it safe.
Spanish Exempla: Keller.
City without provisions but with much money starves.
Man, lion, and bear in pit.

Bear tells lion not to eat the man, since he would grow
hungry again. Rather they should have the man use his intelligence to get them
out. Chauvin III 64 No. 29.

content: Defences by strengthening one’s own weakest spots.
child: Ears stopped with wax to avoid enchanting song.

Odysseus and the Sirens.
Chauvin VII 98 No. 375 n. 4; Köhler-Bolte I 125; Irish myth: *Cross; Italian
Novella: Rotunda; Greek: Fox 137, 263; India: *Thompson-Balys.
Cotton put in ears so as not to hear abusive words.

Monkeys planning to found a city desist lest with walls up
it will be easier to catch them than before.
Wienert FFC LVI *61 (ET 240), 108 (ST 200); Halm Aesop No. 361.

content: Man slays another in order not to be slain himself.
child: Son slays father in order not to be slain himself.

content:
Wise man before entering a quarrel considers how it will
end.

Wesselski Bebel II 110 No. 35; *Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 765.

Youthful fencer yields to infuriated opponent who has
picked up a pestle.

“Two against me. I
surrender.” Spanish: Childers.
Make use of proper seasons for crops.
child:
Lazy boy vainly asks God of the Seasons to delay the
plowing season.

One bird escapes as hunter bends his bow; other remains and
is shot.

(Told also of fish.) *Type 246;
Wienert FFC LVI 61 (ET 233), 108 (ST 205); Halm Aesop No. 85; Chauvin II 88.

King Log. Zeus has given them a log as king, but they find him too
quiet. He then gives them a stork who eats them. Wienert FFC LVI *78 (ET 436),
110 (ST 217); Halm Aesop No. 76; *Crane Vitry 143 No. 24; Lithuanian: Balys
Index No. *277; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. *277; Russian: Andrejev No. 277;
Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Lion as king of animals reinstated after elephant is tired.

Lion suitor allows his teeth to be pulled and his claws to
be cut.

He is then killed. Wienert FFC LVI
45 (ET 32), 70 (ET 344), 107 (ST 198); Halm Aesop No. 249; *Basset RTP XXVI
126; Africa: Weeks Jungle 450.

Robbers persuaded to give hero sword with which they are
afterwards killed.

content: Avoiding places which have been fatal to others.
child:
Fox sees all tracks going into lion‘s den but none coming
out.

He saves himself. Wienert FFC LVI *53
(ET 131), 96 (ST 92); Halm Aesop No. 246, cf. No. 262; Jacobs Aesop 217 No. 73;
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *50A; India: Thompson-Balys; N. A Indian
(Tuxtapec): Mechling JAFL XXV 203; Africa (Angola): Chatelain 189, (Hottentot):
Bleek 19 No. 10; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 243 No. 18.

Avoid enemies‘ revenge either by making peace and
friendship or by killing them all.

So says
old man to conqueror. Pauli (ed. Bolte) Nos. 544, 545.

Advice not to rob women while they are alone, for fear of
returning husbands’ revenge.
Palamides, having injured Ulysses, seeks advice from him.

Following the advice proves fatal. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No
441.

Bird hears voices from within unhatched eggs and flies
away: voices plot to dine on their bird-mother when they are born.

content: Mark the way one is going in an unfamiliar country.

child: Fox with lion protector goes hunting alone and is killed.
Wienert FFC LVI *59 (ET 214), 92 (ST 58); Halm Aesop No. 41.

Foolishness of taking on too strong a partner: crow crowds
sparrow out of its nest.

Cannot escape hunter; peacock flies off. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content: Defence when one needs it most.
child:
Armor ordered thin in front and thick in back, since it
would be most needed in flight.

content: Alliances which make both parties more vulnerable.
child: Rat and frog tie paws together to cross marsh.

Carried off by falcon. *Chauvin II 123 No. 117; Scala Celi
73a No. 416; *Crane Vitry 135 No. 3; Spanish Exempla: Keller; India:
Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 124 (cf. No. 125).

Jackal and leopard tie tails together for mutual
protection.

Frightened, they run apart and
injure each other. India: Thompson-Balys.

Ass turns on his driver who would save him from falling
over the precipice.

Wienert FFC LVI 72 (ET
375), 118 (ST 283); Halm Aesop No. 335.

Tame doves close wild ones in trap and thus help common
enemies.
Tame fox helps dogs against wild foxes.

Is no longer trusted by
latter. Nouvelles Récréations No. 29.

content: Foolishness of alliances with the weak.
child:
Foxes desert their allies, the hares, when they foresee
defeat by the eagle.

Wienert FFC LVI 48
(ET 64), 106 (ST 187); Halm Aesop No. 236.

content: Consolation for misfortune found in food.
child: Consoled by a drop of honey.

Man in pit surrounded by
perils thus comforts himself. **Kuhn Der Mann in Brunnen (Stuttgart, 1888);
*Chauvin II 85 No. 17, III 100 No. 6; Bødker Exempler 276 No. 16; Herbert
Catalogue of Romances III 12; *Crane Vitry 191 No. 134; Alphabet No.
623.--Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Man on sinking ship eats salt.

Otherwise he will not enjoy the large amount of water that
he must drink. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 235; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Mouse (fly) dying in meat tub is happy that he has eaten to
satisfaction.

Wienert FFC LVI *64 (ET
274), *143 (ST 495); Halm Aesop No. 292.

content: Consolation by thinking of some good aspect of a situation.
child:
Dying toad thus comforts his paramour, the frog, whom he is leaving neither
married nor widow nor maiden and pregnant. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 38 No. 288A*.

content: Comfort in the contemplation of impossible pleasure.
child:
Chased from chicken coop by dogs. When he stumbles he says, “What a
fine opportunity to dance if I had time!” Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 33 No. 135A,
Espinosa Jr. No. 24.
Fox about to be hanged asks to be allowed to see geese.

content:
Mutual and undeserved compliments: donkey to camel, “What a
beauty you are”; latter answers, “What a sweet voice you have.”
Consolation by thinking of the past.
child:
Unsuccessful fishermen console themselves that their
earlier high hopes balance up their disappointment.

Wienert FFC LVI 66 (ET 300), 133 (ST 324); Halm Aesop No.
23.

content: Apparent beauty may be of the least importance.

Ruler admires jewels‘s beauty but neglects to inquire
about their marvelous virtues. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Latter wastes time, former not. Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. *2445.
Practical knowledge more vital than theoretical.
child: The bookman and the boatman: each ignorant of other‘s work.

Bookman’s swimming saves their lives. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Solomon, permitted by God to make any request, asks wisdom.
Granted wisdom and wealth. Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: *Neuman.

content: Health chosen as the most precious thing.
Quality of offspring preferred to quantity.
child:
Lioness thus answers fox (hog) who twits her that she has only one cub. Wienert
FFC LVI 44 (ET 20), 142 (ST 477); Halm Aesop No. 240.

content: Useful and ugly preferred to expensive and beautiful.
child:
King who experiences the cultural civilization of an empire
in dream would rather be poor and primitive.
Fox and noisy but empty drum.

Chauvin II 86 No. 21; Bødker
Exempler 278 No. 20; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Little coin in empty bottle noisy.

Man advised to choose good poor man for his daughter’s
husband rather than rich man.
Man criticizes the devil because his deeds are not fair.

Devil says that they are strong nevertheless. Hence strong
speakers rather than clever are to be preferred. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 609.
Hero, despising weapons, fights with fists alone.
Athena chooses olive tree because of fruitfulness.

Sparrows and crickets ask peasant to leave tree standing.
He refuses, but when he finds honey in the tree he consents. Wienert FFC LVI 71
(ET 350), 143 (ST 494); Halm Aesop No. 102.

content: Choice between short and dangerous or long and sure way.

child:
Dog and hog dispute over their children: worth lies not in
speed.

Wienert FFC LVI 44 (ET 19), 142 (ST
478); Halm Aesop No. 409.

Contest between rose and amaranth: worth lies not in
beauty.

Wienert FFC LVI 43 (ET 4), *142
(ST 484); Halm Aesop No. 384.
Pine and thornbush dispute as to their usefulness.

Beauty of form does not give worth; pine grows slowly but
it will withstand storms. Wienert FFC LVI 44 (ET 15), 74 (ET 398), *142 (ST
483); Halm Aesop No. 125.
Fox and panther contest in beauty.

Fox’s spirit worth more than panther‘s skin. Wienert FFC
LVI *43 (ET 1), 142 (ST 482); Halm Aesop No. 42.
Peacock proved to be bad king.

Chosen because of beauty; too weak to defend his flock.
Wienert FFC LVI 47 (ET 63), 90 (ST 22), 142 (ST 480); Halm Aesop No. 398; Dh IV
185ff.
Peacock and crane in beauty contest.

Better be able to soar like crane than to strut about like
peacock. Wienert FFC LVI 43 (ET 3), 142 (ST 479); Halm Aesop No. 397.

Contest in beauty between swallows and crows (ants and
flies): worth lies not in beauty.

Wienert
FFC LVI 43 (ET 5, 9), 124 (ST 330), 142 (ST 482); Halm Aesop No. 415.

Choice of a learned crow: a dead cat better than a golden
crown.

In dividing property clever younger brother takes hind part
of buffalo, upper part of tree, and use of curtain during night.

content: Among many vain words may be found some of wisdom.

child: Father with handsome son and hideous daughter.

Advises both to look in mirror daily lest son exchange
handsome face for bad character; daughter to triumph over face by good manners.
Wienert FFC LVI 83 (ET 494), 149 (ST 536).

content:
Wienert FFC LVI 83 (ET 496), 142 (ST 485); Halm Aesop No.
369.
Choice between flattering lies and unflattering truths.
child:
Raven drowns his young who promise to aid him when he
becomes old.

He saves one who admits he
will not help, because he will have to carry his own young. Lithuanian: Balys
Index No. *244; Finnish: Aarne FFC V No. 33*.

content: Presumptuous smith chants the Divine Comedy.

Dante throws his tools in the street. Blacksmith: “You
ruin my work!” Dante: “You ruin mine!” Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
child: Dante beats a mule driver who chants the Divine Comedy.

content: Boaster of victory over a weaker person reprimanded.

After one day of schooling children are ordered by their
father to cease associating with the unlearned.
Day after Feast Day disputes importance with Feast Day.

Former reprimanded. Wienert FFC LVI 43 (ET 10), 92 (ST
52); Halm Aesop No. 133.
Hare demands equal rights for all animals.

Reprimanded for presumption. Wienert FFC LVI 57 (ET 181),
92 (ST 43); Halm Aesop No. 241.
Kid perched on house jeers at wolf.

(Cf. †J978.) Jacobs
Aesop 204 No. 16; Wienert FFC LVI 56 (ET 162), 112 (ST 231); Halm Aesop No.
135.

(Bull in china shop.) Only breaks the pots *Wienert FFC LVI 40; Halm
Aesop No. 190.
One cock takes glory of another’s valor.

Victor in cock fight crows over his victory. He is taken
off by eagle. A second cock then comes out from hiding and struts about among
the hens. Wienert FFC LVI 57 (ET 180), 92 (ST 56); Halm Aesop No. 21.
Flies try to drink water from elephant‘s ears.

child: Ass in lion’s skin unmasked when he raises his voice.

**DeCock Volkssage 184ff.; Wienert FFC LVI 57 (ET 175,
176), *91 (ST 38), 93 (ST 69); Halm Aesop Nos. 333, 336; Jacobs Aesop 211 No.
49; *Chauvin II 224 No. 22. -- Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys,
Penzer V 99 n. 3.

Type 244; Wienert FFC LVI 47, 57 (ET 61, 173), *93 (ST 66,
67, 68); Halm Aesop Nos. 200, 201, 201b; Jacobs Aesop 205 No. 21; Scala Celi
80b No. 461; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Crow tries to prophesy like raven: detected by his voice.

Wienert FFC LVI 73, (ET 387), 92 (ST 42); Halm Aesop No.
212.
Weasel paints self to deceive mice.

Detected. Wienert FFC LVI *53 (ET 133), 87 (ST 7); Halm
Aesop No. 87.

Painted jackal admitted neither to the peacocks nor to the
jackals.
King of jackals captured because of his large banner.

Thinks that the clog on his neck is a decoration. Wienert FFC LVI 57 (ET 183),
91 (ST 34); Halm Aesop No. 224.
Bad singer thinks he is talented: driven from theatre.

Wienert FFC LVI 82 (ET 481), 93 (ST 72); Halm Aesop No.
193.
Bad writer who praises himself reprimanded.

Flute-player thinks song meant for the prince is sung to
him.

Punished for presumption. Wienert FFC
LVI 81 (ET 478), 93 (ST 71).
Ass who carried divine image thinks people bow before him.

Wienert FFC LVI 57 (ET 177), 94 (ST 74); Halm Aesop No.
324.
Disdain of the wolf for the dog.

Is fleeing from dog’s master not from him. Wienert FFC LVI
*55 (ET 150), 91 (ST 33); Halm Aesop No. 230.
Gnats think they have thrown horse down.

He has only rolled over. *Type 281; Russian: Andrejev No.
281; India: Thompson-Balys.
Crow thinks harvesters are stealing his grain.

Woman in finery in church thinks people are standing up to
see her when they rise at gospel reading.
Spider thinks that it has held back the wind.
Gnats apologize for lighting on bull’s horn.

He had not felt their weight. Wienert FFC LVI *57 (ET
186), 92 (ST 49); Halm Aesop No. 235; India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia:
DeVries‘s list No. 136.

Raven riding on bull’s horns thinks he has brought bull
home.

Crow alighting on falling tree thinks his weight made it
fall.

Penzer III 70 n. 1; Bloomfield Am
Journ. Philol. XL 1.
Glowworm thinks he shines like stars.

Fox thinks his elongated shadow at sunrise makes him as
large as elephant.

Jackal falls into dye vat, tries to pose as peacock:
detected.
Animals each think moon shines for his benefit.
Owl thinks echoes of his hoots are sounds of praise.
Rat imagines himself owner of camel.
He is attached to camel by string. India: Thompson-Balys.
Rag accidentally in king’s wardrobe thinks it is a ribbon.

content: Lowly animal tries to move among his superiors.
child: Ass follows after lion and is punished.

Ass and cock are surprised by lion. Cock crows and scares
lion, who runs. Ass thinks that he has scared lion and pursues. Wienert FFC LVI
57 (ET 174), 92 (ST 53); Halm Aesop No. 323.

Flees at lion‘s roar. Wienert FFC LVI 57 (ET 184), 91 (ST 35); Halm Aesop No.
226.
Ass who has worked with ox thinks himself equal to ox.

Wienert FFC LVI 57 (ET 178), 91 (ST 39); Halm Aesop No.
104.
Frog heaps abuse on bullock, who scorns him.

content: Lowly tries in vain to be greater than he is.
child: Frog tries in vain to be as big as ox.

Bursts. Jacobs Aesop 205 No. 22; Wienert FFC LVI 58 (ET
192), 93 (ST 61); Halm Aesop No. 84; *Crane Vitry 145 No. 29; India:
Thompson-Balys.
Fish swells with pride until it bursts.
Bird tries to puff itself up to look like peacock.
Titmouse ruffles feathers to seem big as a bear.

Her young ones know her. Type 228; Africa (Hottentot):
Bleek 32 No. 16.

Master sees him and says, “Now that you are emperor
remember your humble master.” Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Master asks: “What would you do for me if you were king?”
Answer: “Give you 100 ducats.” Master beats him for insufficient consideration.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Servant asks master for arms of knighthood.
Is given a stalk of garlic. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Is told that he can be made rich but not noble. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.
Old simpleton resolves to become a senator.

He is made to believe that he is wanted as an archer and
is so frightened that he dies. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content: Foolish boast of ancestry by lowly.
child: Mule as descendant of king‘s war-horse.
Fox claims that certain statues are of his ancestors.

Ape shows that he is a liar. Wienert FFC LVI *44 (ET 17),
100 (ST 140); Halm Aesop No. 43.

content:
Presumptuous man before the works of Michelangelo says: “I
too am a master”.
Ambitious branch chosen king of trees.

Vine and fig tree have refused. Scala Celi 8b No. 55;
Judges 9: 8.
Empress sews and shows she is not too noble to work.
King of humble lineage cannot be flattered.
King shows humility by mingling with common people.
child:
King David dances with common youths before the Ark of the
Covenant.

He humbles self to please God.
Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Opposing wise men humble themselves and become friends.
Abbot to avoid vainglory receives judge in rags.

child:
Men not chosen for their ignorance; else he should have
reached heaven.

Upbraided for not knowing
answer to question, man answers that he was chosen for his position because of
what he knew, not of what he did not know. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 224
No. 462.

content:
King has earthen vessels placed on table among the golden
ones.

He had formerly been a potter and
prefers the vessels which he had made to the ones now molding him. Spanish:
Childers.

child: King orders piece of cloth shown after his death.

The measure of all that
he has taken with him to the grave. Herbert III 10; *Crane Vitry 185 No. 119;
Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 24; Wesselski Mönchslatein 67 No. 54; Spanish
Exempla: Keller.

King refuses to have fine tomb erected for him since his
stay on earth is so unimportant.

Rich man humbled by realization that he cannot take his
wealth with him.

content: Mole pretends that he sees, smells, and hears.

His mother tells him to claim no more senses than he has.
Wienert FFC LVI 63 (ET 260), 101 (ST 146); Halm Aesop No. 71.
Humility one of the qualifications of a prophet.
Judge should possess humility and modesty.
Humility of the wise “Sons of the East”.

Noble and ugly holy man embraces man who calls him ugly,
saying he loves those who see him as he really is.
Good shepherd shears his sheep; does not skin them.

Emperor thus replies to suggestion of a new tax to be laid
on the people. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 742.
One should not attempt to change his color.
child: Negro tries in vain to be washed white.

Wienert FFC LVI *46 (ET 48), *87 (ST 5); Halm Aesop No.
13; India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
Scorned suitor consoles himself by realization that a wife
who did not love him would be constant source of trouble.
Animal should not try to change his nature.
child: Crab comes ashore: killed by fox.

Wienert FFC LVI 50 (ET 91), 90 (ST 28); Halm Aesop No.
186.
Kite tries to neigh like a horse.

Loses his voice and gains nothing. Wienert FFC LVI *46 (ET
52), 90 (ST 27); Halm Aesop No. 170.
Camel tries in vain to dance.

Wienert FFC LVI 46 (ET 46, 47), *88, 90 (ST 10, 20); Halm
Aesop No. 182, 365.
Ass tries in vain to play lyre.
Wolf tries in vain to be doctor.

Only increases patient’s suffering. Wienert FFC LVI 46 (ET
40), 122 (ST 309).
Crow tries to imitate partridge‘s walk.

Only spoils his own.
Chauvin II 106 No. 70; Bødker Exempler 303 No. 73; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Mouse, bird, and sausage keep house together.

When they exchange duties all goes wrong. *Type 85; *BP I
206, III 558; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 135.

Elephant, giraffe, snake, and ant try keeping house
together: requirements different.
Ass tries to get a cricket‘s voice.
Lizard tries to make himself as long as snake.

Kills himself. Wienert FFC LVI 58 (ET 189), 93 (ST 62);
Halm Aesop No. 388.

Fox tries to mask as dove, but loses all thoughts of
murder.

Camel and jackal exchange food: camel is led by his good
friend to thorny fruit and thorn sticks in his throat.
Frog wants to be shod like a horse.

Jackal accidentally made king but joins other jackals in
howling at night.
Snake wants to act as pet like parrot: killed.
Frogs want to collect honey like bees.

content:
Peacock spends so much time preening for coronation that
birds become impatient and make the owl king instead.
One should not be too greedy.
child:
Kite tries to carry off so many partridges that he drops
them all.

Herbert III 40ff.; Hervieux IV
211 No. 38; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Finds hunter, gazelle,
and wild boar dead. Tries first to eat the bowstring, and is mortally wounded.
Chauvin II 95 No. 47; Bødker Exempler 292 No. 51; Spanish Exempla: Keller;
India: Thompson-Balys.

Greedy man keeps demanding one more thing from complacent
man;

at last is magically blinded.
Campbell-McKay No. 21.
Greedy pig looks up into tree for figs.
This causes his death. Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Greedy man dissatisfied with gold looks for jewels;

finds only iron and eventually nothing. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Fowler wants two rubies as ransom for a caught goose;
loses goose and both rubies. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Animal gives wise example to man.
child: One wild goat steps over another.

They thus pass each other uninjured on a cliff. This shows
advantage of peaceableness. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 403.
Ass refuses to drink after it has had enough.
Thus teaches lesson to master. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 239.

Trained deer drinks wine till he breaks his leg but
thereafter abstains.

Thus teaches lesson
to master. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 240.

Woman will not follow donkey on safe path: attacked by
robbers.

Squirrel tries to dip out lake with his tail: difficulty of
reforming the world.
Big fish eat little: robber will plunder weak neighbors.

content:
Mouse teaches her child to fear quiet cats but not noisy
cocks.
Wisdom learned from example of insects.
Crow inspects the three worlds in search of happiness.
Animal behavior teaches man what to avoid.
child:
Cock’s second mate lets her stepchildren starve: woman
warns husband accordingly.

content:
Two fools in the habit of striking people are brought
together when they strike each other until they appreciate the value of peace.
Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 38.
Why great man plays with children.

This is to be learned only when one has children himself.
Anecdote of Agesilaus. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 738.
Enemies can be won more by kindness than cruelty.
Romans learn this by experience. Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Man learns the fear of Death by meeting Life.

Life (old woman) beheads him and replaces his head
backwards. Simpleton left in fear for hours before head is readjusted. Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

child:
counsel proved wise by experience. Barber hired to cut king’s throat sees on
the bottom of the basin the words ”Whatever you do, do wisely and think of the
consequences.“ He drops the razor and confesses. *Type 910C; *Krappe Bulletin
Hispanique XXXIX 20 No. 69; Alphabet No. 156; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish:
bin Gorion Born Judas IV 172, 283; India: *Thompson-Balys.

counsel proved wise by experience. Man returns home and sees someone sleeping
with his wife. Though he thinks it is a paramour, he restrains himself and
finds that it is a newborn son. *Type 910B; Chauvin II 157; Irish myth: Cross;
Icelandic: Boberg; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India:
*Thompson-Balys. Cf. Wienert FFC LVI 37; Phaedrus III No. 10.

”Never attack anyone before unsheathing and returning sword
three times“:

counsel proved wise by
experience. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

After sleeping you will feel differently about suicide.
Spanish: Childers.
”Do not draw your sword against the innocent“:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
”Do not uncover weapon in an assembly“:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
”Do not shed the blood of women“:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
”Do not go where an old man has a young wife“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Discovers a murder in
an inn. *Type 910B; Christiansen Norske Eventyr 115; Irish myth: *Cross.
”Do not marry a girl from abroad“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Robbers encountered.
*Type 910B; Scala Celi No. 788; Herbert III 99; Irish myth: *Cross; Spanish
Exempla: Keller.
”Do not prefer a new road to an old one.“

Those who take the new one are killed by robbers. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

”Take side road rather than main one where three roads
meet“:

counsel proved wise by experience.
India: Thompson-Balys.

counsel proved wise by experience. (Cf.
†J266.) Jewish: Neuman.
”Do not ask questions about extraordinary things“:

counsel proved wise by
experience. Those who ask question killed. Köhler-Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. VI 169ff.
(Gonzenbach No. 81); Spanish Exempla: Keller.

”Do not cross a bridge without dismounting from your
horse“;

counsel proved wise by experience. Man breaks leg. Type 910B; Wesselski Märchen
219 No. 32.

counsel proved wise by
experience. Man loses wife on wager. Wesselski Märchen 219 No. 32.

counsel
proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.

counsel proved wise by experience. At last the man is
treated shamefully. *Type 910A; Christiansen Norske Eventyr 115.

Guest stays so long that host gives him black bread
instead of white. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 52; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

counsel proved wise by experience. Type 910A; Christiansen
Norske Eventyr 115.

”Do not walk half a mile with a man without asking his
name“:

counsel proved wise by experience.
Man runs race unwittingly with his wife’s paramour and loses his wife on the wager. (Cf. †J21.8.) *Type
910B; Wesselski Märchen 219 No. 32.
”Rue not a thing that is past“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Man lets bird go and
then, having listened to bird‘s false declaration that she had a precious gem in her body, he
tries to climb a tree after her and falls. *BP IV 149 n. 2; Gaster Exempla 256
No. 390; *Paris Légendes du moyen âge 225ff.; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX
24; Alphabet No. 191; Oesterley Gesta Romanorum No. 167.

counsel proved wise by
experience. Man believes when bird tells him that she has a precious gem in her
body. (Cf. †J21.12, †K604.) *BP IV 149 n. 2; Alphabet No. 191; Gaster Exempla
256 No. 390; Paris Légendes du moyen âge 225ff.; Oesterley Gesta Romanorum No.
167; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

counsel proved wise by
experience. (Cf. †K604.) *BP IV 149 n. 2; Alphabet No. 191; Gaster Exempla 256
No. 390; *G. Paris Légendes du moyen âge 225ff.

”If you wish to hang yourself, do so by the stone which I
point out“:

counsel proved wise by
experience. Father has left money which will fall out when the spendthrift son
goes to hang himself in despair. ”The Heir of Linne.“ *Type 910D; *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 709; Chauvin V 133 No. 63, *VIII 94 No. 65; Child V 12f.; Clouston
Tales II 53; Italian: Basile Pentamerone IV No. 2, Rotunda; Japanese: Ikeda.
”Stay at church till mass is finished“:

counsel proved wise by
experience. Delay saves youth from death. *Cosquin Études 73ff.; Irish: Beal
XXI 314, O’Suilleabhain 38; Icelandic: Boberg;
Japanese: Ikeda.

counsel proved wise by experience. Wife so modest she will
not travel with husband (adulteress); priest so pious he will not tread on worm
(thief). Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas IV 22, 275, Neuman.
”Start your journey early in the day“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Jewish: bin Gorion Born
Judas III 100, 304, Neuman.
”Prepare for night camp while it is still day“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Jewish: bin Gorion Born
Judas III 100, 304, Neuman.
”Do not cross a swollen stream until it has run down“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Jewish: bin Gorion Born
Judas III 100, 304, Neuman.
”Do not tell a secret to a woman“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Nouvelles de Sens No.
7; Irish myth: *Cross; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *911; Italian Novella:
Rotunda; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas III 100, 304, *Neuman; India:
*Thompson-Balys.

counsel proved wise by experience. Man seeking explanation for
being in debt arises earlier and catches his servants stealing. (Cf. †H588.1.)
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
”Do not make a horse run down hill“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Horse breaks its neck.
Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 52; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

counsel proved wise by experience. Breaking of father’s
first counsel causes the breaking of all the others. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
”Don‘t be too greedy in making a trade“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Man refuses fifty
ducats for horse. Horse suddenly dies. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

counsel proved wise by experience. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *911; Italian
Novella: Rotunda.
”Do not trust a ruler who rules by reason alone“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. *911; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
”Keep head dry, feet warm, and eat meat“:

counsel proved wise by experience. King recovers from
illness. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
”Never have to do with a woman unless wed to her“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

”Do not marry a woman before seeing her and finding her to
be your equal“:

counsel proved wise by
experience. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
”Do not marry more than one woman“.

Man who wanted three, marries one and is weakened greatly.
Spanish Exempla: Keller.
”Bathe by yourself and not in the common bathing place“:

counsel proved wise by experience. Man forgets purse in
bath house. India: Thompson-Balys.

counsel proved wise by experience. Man thus saves self
from falling into well. India: *Thompson-Balys.
”When in a strange place look about you“:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
”Do not sit on a bed without touching it first“:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.

(not his own fancy): counsel proved wise by experience.
Thus finds money on body of dead traveler. India: Thompson-Balys.
”Neglect not what four or five people say“:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.

counsel proved wise by experience. Helpful crab saves from
attack by crocodile. India: *Thompson-Balys.

counsel proved wise by
experience. (Cf. †J21.22.) India: Thompson-Balys.
”May God spare you from an evil man or evil woman.“

To teach a friend the wisdom of this greeting a man
borrows money and then his creditor‘s coat from him. In court the lender is
discredited. Spanish: Childers.
counsel proved wise by experience. India: *Thompson-Balys.

Don’t require honor from a strange country”: counsel proved
wise by experience.

“Be cautious before allowing yourself to fall asleep in a
strange place”:

counsel proved wise by
experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.

“A stranger does not close his eyes in sleep lest he close
them in death”:

counsel proved wise by
experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
“He who lies awake gains; he who sleeps loses”:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: *Thompson-Balys.

“Before eating food at a strange place throw some at an
animal and watch”:

counsel proved wise by
experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
“A country not examined in disguise will always be ruined”:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
“Lean upon no relation in the hour of distress”:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: *Thompson-Balys.
“Do not undertake to be an arbitrator without being asked”:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
“Do not make friends with a policeman (soldier)”:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: *Thompson-Balys.

“You can only call your wife your own so long as she is
with you”:

counsel proved wise by
experience. India: *Thompson-Balys.
“Do not send your wife for a long visit to her parents”:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: *Thompson-Balys.

counsel proved wise by experience. A purse full of money
was found in dead man’s pocket by gravedigger. India: Thompson-Balys.

“Never give a cup made of a single ruby as a present to the
king”:

counsel proved wise by experience.
India: Thompson-Balys.
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
“Do not stand and watch two people fighting”:

counsel proved wise by experience. Man does so and is
called by both parties to depose in favor of both or he will be beheaded.
India: Thompson-Balys.

Disciple who stays in a city where everything is sold at
one price finds justice is not even there.
“Never be rude to a self-made man of low birth”:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
“Never publish a man‘s sin if you can help it”:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
“Never dismiss and old servant for his first fault”:
counsel proved wise by experience. India: Thompson-Balys.

“When a man attacks you, kill him whether he be king or
prince”:

counsel proved wise by
experience. India: Thompson-Balys.

Boy who says “I know” gets into all sort of difficulties;
now says “I don’t know.”
“Nothing happens that does not work for one‘s good”:
counsel proved wise is experience. India: Thompson-Balys.
“He who throws himself against a wave is overthrown by it”:

content: Precepts of the lion to his sons.

Only the younger keeps them and is successful. Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 20.
child: Precept of the lion to his sons: beware of man.
Precept of the lion to his sons: honor the woods.

Precept of the lion to his sons: keep peace with the
neighbors.

content: Merchants try honesty for a year and find that it pays.

So advised by priest when they said that they could not do
business without dishonesty. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 394; Irish: Beal XXI 307,
O’Suilleabhain 25.

Difficulty of thinking of God when occupied with worldly
affairs.

Shown by test: holy man made to
carry milk without spilling. So occupied he forgets to think of God. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Wisdom acquired by hanging in a tree.

child: Man buys a pennyworth of wit.

Nouvelles de Sens No. 6; English: Wells 179 (A Peniworth
of Witte); West Indies: Flowers 474.
Man to bring wife a purseful of sense.
Fool is told to get a pottle of brains.

He tries to buy them. He finally learns that advice was to
marry a clever girl. England: Baughman.

*Types 910A, 910B; *Fb “råd”; Spanish Exempla: Keller;
India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 229.

content:
Ungrateful son
reproved by naïve action of his own son: preparing for old age.

Man gives
his old father half a carpet to keep him warm. Child keeps the other half and
tells his father that he is keeping it for him when he grows old. *Bédier
Fabliaux 463f.; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) Nos. 436, 760; Crane Vitry 260 No. 288;
Herbert III 25; *BP II 135, IV 172 n. 14; Scala Celi No. 530; *Krappe Bulletin
Hispanique XXXIX 41.--Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *996; Russian: Andrejev No.
*982; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Chinese: Eberhard FFC
CXX 256f. No. 201; Japanese: Ikeda.
child:
Ungrateful
son reproved by naïve action of his own son: preparing for old age (wooden
drinking cup or bowl).

Father tells son not to drag him past the threshold,
because he had dragged his own father only up to that point when he had thought
of putting him out of his house. Spanish: Childers.

Seducer about to seduce mother of child refrains when child
wisely remarks that he is sad because his father has left his mother exposed to
such dangers.
Clever prince overrules seemingly just decisions of king.

content: Learning the virtue of patience from children.

When their meals are stolen, they quietly search for them.
India: Thompson-Balys.
Parents‘s misdeeds innocently betrayed by children.
Italian Novella: Rotunda; West Indies: Flowers 474.
child: The wine needs no further water.

Guests asks small daughter of innkeeper for water to put
into his wine. She says, “You will not have to do that for mother poured a
whole tubful into the cask today.” *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 374.
Adulteress betrayed by little child‘s remark.
Child unwittingly betrays his mother‘s adultery.

Tells father not to step across chalk line drawn around
secretary; if he does secretary may do to him what he did to Mother the other
day. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 23.

content: Monk shames accuser by telling parable.

Wind, Water, and Modesty (Sense of Shame). The first two
give their addresses but the third says she has no address as no one wants her.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Ruler learns lesson from the example of an exiled king.

Rewards the exile rather than a successful merchant.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Unscrupulous conduct of business learned from observation
of usurer’s own practices and used against him.
child:
Ruler learns lesson from seeing city governed by king as
uncharitable as he.

content:
Sight of deformed witches causes man to release wife from
spinning duty.

They tell him that their deformity has come from too much
spinning. *Type 501; *BP I 109ff. (Gr. No. 14); **Von Sydow Två Spinnsagor.
Army saved from ambush by observation of birds‘ movements.

Birds fly from part of woods in which ambushed men lie.
Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 541; Japanese: Ikeda.
King observes retaliation among animals: becomes just.

Dog breaks fox’s foot; man breaks dog‘s; horse breaks
man’s leg; horse steps in hole and breaks his. Chauvin II, 116 No. 93.
child:
Understanding of universality of death from watching
animals prey on one another.

King descends to bottom of sea in glass barrel to learn
wisdom from observing fish.

content:
Wisdom from robbers (thugs) who disguise selves and show
cruel princess how she should treat her husband.

child: Other biblical heroes as wise men.

content:
Wisdom taught by parable: cloud which gives rain to
thirsting crops or drops it in ocean.

Congregation follows evil ways of priest. He walks in mud but they will not
follow him. He thus shows them the folly of following his evil ways. Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 68.
The gray and the black hairs: enemies reconciled.

Duke summons two inveterate enemies. Has them tear out one
of his hairs, one a gray, the other a black. Both pain him equally. He shows
how their quarrels hurt him. They are reconciled. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 401.

child:
Solomon proves to his mother the inferiority of woman’s
wisdom.

Minister taught by parable to make obeisance to the new
king.

content: The dishes of the same flavor.

Man thus shown that one
woman is like another and dissuaded from his amorous purpose. *Basset 1001
Contes II 25; *Wesselski Märchen 209; Boccaccio Decameron I No. 5 (Lee 17),
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *981; Russian: Andrejev No. *981 (II); Italian
Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child: Monotony of restriction to one‘s favorite food.

Counselor refuses to arrange extramarital pleasures for
his lord. Ruler feeds him only his favorite food until the counselor protests
the monotony. Ruler drives home his point. Italian Novella: Rotunda, Cent
Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 10.
Society is like a dish: must be properly mixed.

Plates having salt, pepper, fish, etc. not edible without
mixing. India: Thompson-Balys.

Woman gives morsel of various foods to each guest, with
explanation. India: Thompson-Balys.

Parable comparing canons to a stew made of their individual
meals.

content:
Rocks falling together and thread entering needle’s eye
suggest sexual intercourse: hence its beginning.

Men shamed for their cowardice by woman standing naked
before them.

(Usually connected with Jus Primae Noctis [T161]). Wesselski
Archiv Orientální I 83f.; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *2429.

Picking up water thrown on ground no harder than the
undoing of slander.
Chair over fiery pit as figure of precariousness of life.

Boy saves life by showing father foolishness of plowing up
his crop.

Father has been persuaded to
kill child. India: Thompson-Balys.
Bear learns how to catch crabs with his hairy claws.

Crow drops pebbles into water jug so as to be able to
drink.

Wienert FFC LVI 64 (ET 272), 106
(ST 186, 246); Jacobs Aesop 213 No. 55.

Blind man who feels young wolf recognises his savage
nature.

Arrow as man‘s message shows lion how terrible man himself
must be.

Wienert FFC LVI 67 (ET 316), 122
(ST 312); Babrius No. 1; Halm Aesop No. 403; BP II 99.

Encounter with clever children (woman) dissuades man from
visit.

On way to a city meets children and
they are so clever that he turns back home, fearing how clever their parents
must be. *Wesselski Gonnella 118 No. 15, *Hodscha Nasreddin II 227 No. 481;
Japanese: Ikeda.
child:
Cleverness of men disguised as peasants dissuades rivals
from dispute.

Wise men of two rival cities
engage in dispute. One delegation disguises as peasants and debates with their
adversaries. Latter withdraw fearing how clever the educated must be if their
peasants are so learned. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content:
How fine wine must been been to leave so good an odor. Wienert FFC LVI 76 (ET
416), 122 (ST 313); Phaedrus III No. 1; Jacobs Aesop 220 No. 81.
Hare instructs his sons to use their eyes to advantage.

Observation of dying people for a year takes man‘s thoughts
from lust.
Ducklings take to water from instinct.

Bridegroom thus brought to understand bride’s expertness
in lovemaking. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Birds having learned their possible dangers are forced from
nest by mother.

child:
Humble Brahmin teaches king the difference between “mine”
and “thine.

Wisdom learned in underground kingdom: the passions of a
human being could not be satisfied on earth.

content:
Drops of water make hollow in stone: thus repeated
impressions penetrate mind.
child:
Lazy pupil determines to be more diligent by watching man
building home one wattle at a time, and seeing how water fills hole one drop at
a time.

content: Good and bad in all books.

Author says that a prudent man notes only the good in a
vain book; a malicious person, only the bad in a good book. Spanish: Childers.

Man is ordered by Senate to make tyrant stop bloodshed. He
kills himself and family to satiate tyrant of blood. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Account of punishments prepared in hell brings about
repentance.

Type 756B; Andrejev FFC LXIX
120ff.; Irish: Beal XXI 324, 330, 332, O’Suilleabhain 63, 95, 100; India:
Thompson-Balys.

(Cf. †B82.6.) Irish
myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; Estonian: Loorits Grundzüge I 213f., 216ff.,
248f.; Jewish: *Neuman.
child:
Counsel: if you take it you will be sorry; if you don‘t you
will also be sorry.

This advice given hero by helpful horse. *Köhler-Bolte I 468f.,
542.

King questions six doctors: what do you like best of all on
earth? That man has not what he wishes to have.

King questions six doctors: what do you like best of all on
earth? That all joys are mixed with sorrow.

King questions six doctors: what do you like best of all on
earth? That all evil and hypocrisy will have an end.

King questions six doctors: what must you most marvel at on
earth? That those who are most respected are the biggest fools.

King questions six doctors: what must you most marvel at on
earth? That those who speak of spiritual matters are usually the most depraved.

King questions six doctors: what must you most marvel at on
earth? That man lives in a state in which he cannot die.

Crow flying away says, “A wise man remains not in the place
of calamity; but a fool stays there, and sups fear and sorrow.”

Proverbial wisdom: “Seek to win over the accuser, so that
he causes you no annoyance.”

content:
Man says that he is the youngest present, for he does not count the years
before he became monk (or the like). *Chauvin III 108.
Wisdom lost by accepting bribes and gifts.
Wisdom wins contest of wisdom and wealth.
child:
Minister‘s clever daughter-in-law uses wisdom to defeat
Brahmin’s wealth.
Relative pleasures of sexes in love taught by parable.
Father bequeathes four pots to sons:

content: Stones shaken in jar: difficulty in learning many dialects.
Inscription on walls for condensed education.

child: Wisdom from books bought at great price.

(Sibylline). Nine books first offered at certain price.
Finally after this is refused and the owner throws six of them into the fire,
the king pays the same price for three of them. Finds them filled with wisdom.
Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 588.
Wisdom from books of the antediluvians.

content: Wisdom from continual reminder of foolishness in the past.

Unjust judge skinned and his skin stretched over a
footstool kept in the presence of judges, so as to remind them to be just.
Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 118; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Fool digs holes in edge of road.

Only those departing from straight path will fall in.
Truth of principle later seen. India: Thompson-Balys.
Trial rehearsed before stick in the ground as judge.

Köhler-Bolte Zs. f.
Vksk. VI 62 (Gonzenbach No. 8).

Lotus flower flourishes as long as it is in water: king
should not leave castle.
Man kills nest of ants: so God punishes man.

He had formerly envied sailors. Wienert FFC LVI 75 (ET
407), 110 (ST 219); Halm Aesop No. 370.
child: Man bitten by snake fears snake-like rope.

content: Young sparrows have learned to avoid men.

Sparrow quizzes his four young as to how to avoid danger
from men. Their year of experience has taught them enough. BP III 239 (Gr. No.
157); Hervieux Fabulistes latins II 546 No. 70.

Young ass avoids food eaten by animals before being
slaughtered.

Runs to his mother and asks
to have all remains of the hog‘s food taken out. Wienert FFC LVI 72 (ET 374),
110 (ST 221); Chauvin III 51 No. 7.
Serpent (bird) having injured man refuses reconciliation.

He knows that neither
can forget their injuries. Chauvin II 94 No. 43, 102 No. 62; Bødker Exempler
291 No. 47, 301 No. 67; Wienert FFC LVI *69 (ET 331), *127 (ST 352); Babrius
No. 167; Jacobs Aesop 201 No. 6; Halm Aesop Nos. 96, 251, 350; cf. BP II 459;
Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Old racehorse in mill laments vanity of youth.

Wienert FFC LVI *72 (ET 365), 140 (ST 466); Babrius No.
29; Halm Aesop No. 174.
Animal learns through experience to fear men.

In spite of the warning of another animal he approaches
man and is shot. *Type 157; BP II 96; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa
(Hottentot): Bleek 47 No. 23; American Negro: Harris Nights 33 No. 7, 330 No.
57; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 262 No. 62.
child: Tiger, jackal, and bear each learn to fear man.

They report him as head-thumper (he has beaten the tiger),
turn-twister (he has swung jackal by tail), and top-tumbler (he has fallen out
of tree on bear). India: *Thompson-Balys.

content: Dove disregards experience and loses brood.

Rebuilds her nest in the
place where she has lost former brood. Chauvin II 83 No. 6; Bødker Exempler 274
No. 7, 306 No. 82; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Incognito prince, beaten for his courtesy, realizes his
folly and returns home. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

child: Wisdom of hidden old man saves kingdom.

In famine all old men are ordered killed. One man hides
his father. When all goes wrong in the hands of the young rulers, the old man
comes forth, performs assigned tasks, and aids with his wisdom. Type 981*;
*Anderson FFC XLII 182 n. 1; *DeVries FFC LXXIII 220ff.; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
446, cf. No. 538; Fb “gammel” IV 174a; Scala Celi No. 281; *Paudler FFC
CXXI.--Irish myth: *Cross; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *995; Russian: Andrejev
No. 981*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 995*; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII
No. 910F*; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman;
India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 115ff. No. 71.
Wisdom from god as old (one-eyed) man.
Wisdom from old man: always say, “if it pleases God.”
Holy man’s prayer reforms rich man.

Holy man prays, “May God bless everything here that is
good but cause to disappear all that is bad.” Everything disappears. Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 199; India: Thompson-Balys.
Hermit explains why anger is sin.

content:
Irish myth: *Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish:
*Neuman.
child:
Chauvin IX 35 No. 27; Scala Celi No. 103; Spanish Exempla:
Keller.
Philosopher consoles woman for loss of son.

Wisdom from philosopher: give separate greetings to
infants, youths, and old people.
Wisdom from philosopher: worldly honor like shadow.

If one goes toward it, it flees; if one turns his back on
it, it follows and at times catches up with one. Spanish: Childers.
Hero directed on journey by princess.
Serpent directed on journey by his beautiful wife.

King has amours with great men’s wives so as to learn
secrets from them.
Caesar‘s scorn of his wife’s advice leads to disaster.
Wife of usurer saves husband through her prayers.

(Cf. †J154.) Icelandic:
Völsunga saga ch. 33 (31); Þiðriks saga II 254--56, Boberg.
Knowledge from mysterious women met in the forest.
Wisdom from harlot to a king.

content:
Counsel proved wise by
experience. *Cosquin Études 85ff.; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 52; Irish myth:
Cross; Icelandic: Völsunga saga ch. 11, Boberg; Lithuanian: Balys Index No.
*911; Jewish: Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesian: DeVries‘s list No. 230.
child: Dying saint leaves wise message to followers.

Message is cryptic, but is finally made clear. Spanish
Exempla: Keller.
Deity appears in dream and gives instructions or advice.
Wisdom from dream: the leper with the cup of water.
Fate of parents revealed in dream.

Mother shown in Hell; father in Heaven. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Dream advises against the popularizing of science.

content: Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 610; Irish myth: Cross.
child:
Wisdom from fool: make peace before rather than after the
war.

Wisdom from fool: absurdity of tight-rope walker‘s
performance.
Wisdom from fool: the present returned.

Nobleman gives fool a present; he is to give it to no one
who is not a greater fool. Master is dying; doctor tells fool that master is
going to take long journey. Since master is making no preparation, fool gives
him the present. Master thus brought to repentance. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 45.

Fool says he does not want to go to heaven for he wants to
stay with his master, who everyone says is going to hell. Master repents. Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 46.
Solomon pays heed to angel‘s warning.
King prefers educated men as company.

content: Child confined to keep him in ignorance of life.
Useless. *Chauvin III 97 No. 1; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Well-trained kid does not open to wolf.

*Type 123; Wienert FFC LVI 63 (ET 262), 145 (ST 506, 535);
*BP I 37; Dh IV 277f.

Hostile dogs made friendly by having them fight common
enemy, the wolf.

child: House dog blames master for teaching him lazy habits.

Wienert FFC LVI 60 (ET 229), 145 (ST 502); Halm Aesop No.
217.
Man blames master for not correcting him in youth.

content: Untrained colt result of master’s neglect.

Wienert FFC LVI 71 (ET 361), 129 (ST 371); Halm Aesop No.
